para.paratext: A supply of services agreement for use in business-to-business transactions. It is drafted from the customer's perspective.

This document is an agreement for the supply of services in a business-to-business (b2b) context. The relevant services may be provided over a long period (for example, catering services for several years) or a shorter period (a few weeks of training).
All the services to be provided are agreed upfront and set out in a schedule to the agreement, subject to any changes the parties later agree.
The agreement is drafted from the customer's perspective.
The key legal issues to consider when drafting a supply of services agreement are set out below. For a detailed discussion, see Practice note, Supply of services contracts: overview.
Part II of the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982 (SGSA) implies three terms into contracts for services:
The supplier will carry out the services with reasonable care and skill (section 13).

If the time for carrying out the services is not fixed by the contract, left to be fixed in a manner agreed in the contract or determined by the parties' course of dealing, there is an implied term that the supplier will carry out the services within a reasonable time. What is reasonable is a question of fact (section 14).

If the price of the services is not determined by the contract, left to be determined in a manner agreed in the contract or determined by the course of dealing between the parties, there is an implied term that the customer will pay the supplier a reasonable charge. What is reasonable is a question of fact (section 15).
In addition, Part I of the SGSA implies the following terms in relation to goods transferred under a contract for services (for example, spare parts or materials used as part of the services):
The supplier has title to the goods, the customer will enjoy quiet possession of them and the goods are free from encumbrances (section 2).
The goods will correspond with their description (section 3).
The goods will be of satisfactory quality and fit for purpose (section 4).
The goods will correspond with their sample (section 5).

The implied terms in Part I of the SGSA apply to materials used in the services but may not apply to the finished product of the services, such as deliverables (see Practice note, Drafting standard terms and conditions for the supply of services: Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982). A customer wanting to ensure that the finished product is fit for purpose, meets a particular quality and specification, and is free from defects should include express provisions to this effect in its contracts (see clause 4.1(b) and clause 4.1(d)).
The Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977 (UCTA) controls attempts to exclude the SGSA's implied terms or limit liability for their breach as follows:

Exclusions or limitations in relation to the implied terms as to reasonable skill and care, correspondence with description, satisfactory quality, fitness for purpose and correspondence with sample must be reasonable (section 2 and section 7(1A)).
Exclusions or limitations in relation to the implied terms as to title, quiet possession and freedom from encumbrances are void (section 7(3A)).

Subject to the application of UCTA, the parties to a services agreement can negate or vary these implied terms by express agreement (sections 11(1) and 16(1), SGSA). In a customer-friendly services agreement, the customer will often look to include tougher requirements than these implied terms (for example, by requiring the supplier to perform the services to a higher standard than reasonable skill and care).

Limitation of liability (especially the supplier's) is always a key area for negotiation in a supply of services agreement. The supplier is usually at greater risk of facing a damages claim from the customer than vice versa.

As such, the supplier will generally seek to restrict its liability to the customer by inserting a limitation of liability clause. Without a limitation clause, there are no limits on the damages the customer can recover other than common law restrictions on recovery of damages (see Practice note, Damages for breach of contract: an overview: Restrictions on recovery of damages).

Despite this document being a pro-customer agreement, we have included mutual limitations and exclusions of liability at clause 18 because it is unusual for a supplier to accept an agreement with no limitations or exclusions of liability.
For information on limiting liability in b2b contracts, see Practice notes:
Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating.
Limiting liability: interpretation.
Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses.

Under the Transfer of Undertakings (Protection of Employment) Regulations 2006 (SI 2006/246) (TUPE), if there is a "service provision change" (essentially a change in the entity responsible for providing the services), any employees assigned to an organised group whose main purpose is performing those services will automatically transfer to the new service provider on their current employment terms. A service provision change includes the following scenarios:
A customer engages a supplier for the first time to work on its behalf.
A customer appoints a replacement supplier to perform the relevant services on its behalf.
A customer brings the services back "in-house".
(Regulation 3(1)(b), TUPE.)
There is no service provision change where:
The contract is wholly or mainly for the supply of goods for the customer's use (regulation 3(3)(b)).
The activities are carried out in connection with a single specific event or a task of short-term duration (regulation 3(3)(a)(ii)).
The services are not fundamentally the same before and after the change of service provider (regulation 3(2A)).
For more information on when TUPE will apply on a service provision change, see Practice note, TUPE (3): service provision changes.
TUPE is an issue for consideration when services start (TUPE on entry) and when they end (TUPE on exit):

TUPE on entry. Will any of the customer's employees (or employees of the customer's former supplier) transfer from the customer (or its former supplier) to the supplier when the services start? If so, the supplier may want to seek contractual warranties and indemnities from the customer to cover the liabilities which arise from those TUPE transfers.

TUPE on exit. When the services come to an end, will any employees transfer from the supplier to either the customer or to a replacement supplier? If so, what contractual protection is the supplier willing to provide to the customer (or the replacement supplier) to cover the liabilities arising from those TUPE transfers?

As this is a pro-customer agreement, the TUPE on exit provisions are more comprehensive than the TUPE on entry provisions which are usually more likely to benefit the supplier (see Schedule 6). A customer in a strong bargaining position may choose to omit any TUPE on entry provisions, although including some protection for the supplier may reduce the scope for negotiation.
For more information on contractual protection to cover TUPE transfers on entry and exit, see Practice note, Outsourcing agreements: drafting and negotiating employment indemnities and warranties.

This agreement assumes that the provision of services involves the supplier processing personal data for the customer. It includes data processing provisions at clause 13. The clause is drafted to facilitate compliance with the UK GDPR and, if applicable, the EU GDPR.
Under these rules, a processor (the supplier in most cases):

Is subject to direct compliance obligations and may be liable to fines or penalties for breaches. The legislation also specifies the contractual terms that customers, in their capacity as controllers, must include in their contracts with suppliers (as processors).

Cannot engage a subprocessor to carry out the processing activities without the controller's prior written consent. If a subprocessor is appointed, the legislation requires that the data protection obligations in the subprocessing arrangement must mirror those in the main agreement (that is, the agreement between the controller and the processor).
For more information on processor obligations, see Practice note, Processor obligations under UK GDPR.

The UK GDPR also prohibits the transfer of personal data outside the UK unless certain conditions are met. The conditions include the UK making an adequacy decision on the recipient country's data protection regime, or appropriate safeguards being put in place (for example, the use by the controller and processor of standard data protection clauses adopted by the Information Commissioner's Office). There are similar restrictions on transfers outside the EU under the EU GDPR. For more information on cross-border data transfers, see Practice note, Overview of data transfers (UK).

A customer may be subject to various regulatory compliance obligations, which it needs to "flow down" to suppliers within its supply chain. A customer may also be keen to ensure that its supply chain practices are ethical (for example, on issues in relation to human rights or climate change).
The most common legal frameworks that could give rise to compliance obligations are:

Modern Slavery Act 2015 (MSA). The MSA is aimed at combating crimes of slavery and human trafficking. Commercial organisations with a global turnover of Â£36 million or more must publish an annual slavery and human trafficking statement (section 54). The statement must disclose what steps the organisation has taken to ensure that human trafficking is not taking place in any of its supply chains or its business, or state that it has taken no steps. A customer may therefore want to include wording in its services agreements to prohibit the use of forced or trafficked labour by suppliers and require adherence to its anti-slavery policies. For more information, see Practice note, Modern Slavery Act 2015: slavery and human trafficking statement.

Bribery Act 2010 (BA 2010). Of particular concern to businesses in a commercial context is the corporate offence of failure to prevent bribery by an associated person. A commercial organisation will be guilty of the offence if a person associated with it bribes another person intending to obtain or retain business or a business advantage for the commercial organisation (section 7, BA 2010). A person is "associated" with a commercial organisation if it performs services for or on behalf of that organisation. The commercial organisation has a defence if it can show that it had adequate procedures in place to prevent bribery by its associated persons. For more information, see Practice note, Bribery Act 2010: application to commercial agreements.

Criminal Finances Act 2017 (CFA). A relevant body may be criminally liable for failing to prevent the facilitation of tax evasion by its associated persons (Part 3, CFA). A customer's associated persons could include suppliers. A customer may therefore require the inclusion of anti-facilitation of tax evasion provisions in its contracts with suppliers. For more information, see Practice note, Tax offences: failure to prevent facilitation of tax evasion.

Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act 2023 (ECCTA). From 1 September 2025, an in-scope organisation (broadly, a large body corporate or partnership formed or incorporated anywhere in the world) may be criminally liable where it fails to prevent an associated person from committing a fraud offence intending to benefit the organisation (section 199, ECCTA). An in-scope organisation has a defence if it can show that it had in place reasonable fraud prevention procedures. For more information, see Practice note, ECCTA 2023: failure to prevent fraud offence: application to commercial relationships.

This document includes a generic provision at clause 12 that requires the supplier to comply with applicable laws and the various legal and ethical obligations that are identified as the customer's "Mandatory Policies". The customer should assess if a generic clause is sufficient or whether it also wants to include additional duties to comply with specific laws that represent a high risk to the customer. For instance, if the supplier operates in a sector or country that is deemed high risk for bribery and corruption, the customer may want to include a bespoke anti-bribery clause to address this. Optional wording in clause 12 requires the supplier to adhere to specific obligations in relation to bribery, fraud and modern slavery.

charges and payment;

Schedule 1 sets out the details of the services to be provided, including:

Schedule 2 sets out the charges payable for the services.
Schedule 3 sets out key members of the supplier's team who are involved in providing the services.
Schedule 4 sets out the customer's mandatory policies which the supplier must comply with.
Schedule 5 sets out the data processing details.
Schedule 6 sets out the TUPE provisions, including warranties and indemnities, to cover the liabilities associated with any TUPE transfers.
This agreement is drafted on the following assumptions:

Services agreed upfront. This agreement is for the provision of an agreed set of services. It does not provide for the procurement and provision of future work through statements of work (SOWs) under its terms. If this is required, see Standard document, Simple framework services agreement (pro-customer).

B2b. The parties are dealing with each other in the course of their respective businesses, so rules protecting consumers do not apply. This agreement is therefore not suitable for use in business-to-consumer transactions. For resources on consumer law, including business-to-consumer terms and conditions, see Consumer law toolkit.

Pro-customer. The agreement favours the customer. The drafting notes explain where a clause is particularly one-sided and may meet resistance from the supplier. For supplier-friendly drafting, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier).

One contract. The customer party signing the agreement is the only party contracting with the supplier. This is not a master services agreement or framework agreement under which each party and its affiliates can contract with each other for services, although there is optional drafting in clause 3 that could be used to enable customer affiliates to benefit from the services. For a framework agreement in which the main customer's affiliates can order services by entering into call-off contracts with the supplier, see Standard document, Complex framework services agreement.
Terms not industry specific. This agreement does not account for any industry-specific laws or rules that may apply to certain transactions.

UK companies, not public bodies. The parties are companies incorporated in England and Wales. This agreement is not for use by public bodies procuring services. The procurement of services by public bodies is subject to specific procurement rules. For a services agreement that can be used by a public sector body, see Standard document, Services agreement for use by public sector bodies.
English law. The agreement is subject to English law.

The scope of services should be drafted as precisely as possible. Even so, it may not be possible to prescribe every single aspect of the services that the supplier should provide, particularly where the services are focused on outcomes that the supplier should achieve rather than how the supplier gets there. The optional wording in brackets widens the definition of services to include services that are not specifically described in the agreement but which are incidental or ancillary to the services described.

From the customer's perspective, the advantage of including these words is that those incidental and ancillary services will be subject to the same performance obligations as the services described in Schedule 1 and covered by the charges set out in Schedule 2.
By contrast, the supplier is likely to see this drafting as "scope-creep". The supplier will want to be able to charge extra for any ancillary or incidental services.

An argument in favour of the supplier accepting this wording is that the supplier's liability for those incidental and ancillary services will be subject to the supplier's liability cap at clause 18.3(c).

Optional clause 3.1 confirms that the customer is free to purchase similar services from anyone else or supply them itself. If there are no other provisions requiring the customer to buy a certain volume of services from the supplier, then there is no need to include a non-exclusivity provision like this. However, some customers prefer to avoid any misunderstandings on this point.

If the customer has agreed to buy certain services exclusively from the supplier (for example, in return for favourable pricing), replace this wording with an exclusive purchasing clause. See Standard clause, Exclusive purchasing and supply clause: long form.

This clause includes carve-outs from an exclusive purchasing commitment enabling the customer to use an alternative supplier where the supplier cannot deliver (for example, due to a force majeure event).

The customer may want its affiliates to receive services from the supplier. Clause 3.2 to clause 3.3(a) provide optional wording to extend the services to customer affiliates. They can be deleted if the parties do not envisage that customer affiliates will ever need to receive the services.

Extend the services to customer affiliates (see clause 3.2).

Require the supplier to enter into a direct contractual relationship with any customer affiliate which adopts the terms of this agreement (see clause 3.3). For an example of an adoption agreement which could be included as a schedule to this agreement, see Standard document, Adoption agreement.

Require the supplier, alternatively, to service the customer affiliate without a direct contractual relationship being created but with the customer liable for the customer affiliate's acts or omissions.

The supply of Services under this agreement is not an exclusive arrangement. The Customer may purchase services that are the same as or similar to the Services from any third party or provide them itself.
The Customer's Affiliates may receive Services under this agreement.

The Customer may require the Supplier to enter into a written agreement with any of its Affiliates that incorporates the terms of this agreement and creates a direct relationship between the Supplier and the Affiliate (Adoption Agreement). Alternatively, the Customer may require the Supplier to provide Services to an Affiliate without an Adoption Agreement in which case:
the Customer shall procure that the Affiliate complies with the terms of this agreement as if it were a party to this agreement in place of the Customer;
the Customer shall be liable for the acts and omissions of the Affiliate as if they were its own acts and omissions;
the Supplier shall invoice the Affiliate for the Charges and other costs and expenses incurred in relation to the Services provided to the Affiliate;

If the customer pays invoices for services received by a customer affiliate, it may struggle to recover the VAT included in those invoices as it is not the recipient of the services. In that scenario, the VAT is a cost to the customer.

the Customer may, as agent and trustee, enforce the terms of this agreement on behalf of any of its Affiliates and for this purpose the Customer may recover the Affiliate's Losses as if they were its own. In any case in which the Customer does enforce any term in this agreement on behalf of an Affiliate under this clause 3.3(e), that Affiliate may not exercise its rights under clause 3.3(d).

Clause 3.3(d) gives customer affiliates rights in relation to the services they receive. If this clause is included it should be referenced in clause 31.1 as a clause under which third party rights have been created.

Under clause 3.3(e), the customer can enforce the agreement on behalf of its affiliates against the supplier. This is designed to allow the customer to bring claims for itself and its affiliates where they have all suffered loss through the supplier's breach.

There is a general principle in law that a party can only recover loss which it has itself suffered. The drafting attempts to solve this problem by making it clear that the customer is recovering an affiliate's losses as its agent. However, there may still be a risk of a no loss argument for the customer.
If the customer does enforce on behalf of its affiliates, those affiliates cannot also claim directly against the supplier, which is reasonable.

This clause 4 sets out the supplier's principal obligations relating to the services. It includes commitments from the supplier to deliver services on time and to a high standard and remedies for the customer if the supplier fails to do so.
For information on terms implied by law into b2b services agreements, see Drafting note, Implied terms above.
The Supplier shall:
provide the Services and Deliverables in accordance with the terms and conditions of this agreement;

ensure that the Services and Deliverables conform to the specifications, requirements and standards set out in Schedule 1 and that the Deliverables are fit for any purpose expressly or implicitly made known to the Supplier by the Customer;
Clause 4.1(b) requires the supplier to ensure that the services and deliverables conform with the standards and requirements in Schedule 1.

This agreement does not commit the supplier to meeting service levels. If the parties have agreed to include service levels (which could be set out in either the specification of the available services or in a separate schedule), then the agreement needs to expressly commit the supplier to meeting those service levels and deal with reporting against them and the consequences of them not being met. For an example of a service level clause, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: shorter form: clause 7.

perform the Services with [the highest level of care, skill and diligence in accordance with best practice in the Supplier's industry, profession or trade OR the care, skill and diligence expected from a supplier [highly OR reasonably and suitably] skilled and experienced in providing services similar to the Services];

head.headtext: Care and skill in provision of services

para.paratext: The SGSA implies a term that the supplier will carry out the services with reasonable care and skill (section 13). This term can, as here, be varied by appropriate wording to introduce a higher or more industry-specific standard.
The first option sets the highest standard for the supplier to meet. Many suppliers may object to meeting such an onerous standard. The second option is less demanding.

ensure that the Deliverables, and all goods, materials, standards and techniques used in providing the Services, are of the [best quality OR standard expected of a market-leading provider of similar services] and are free from defects in workmanship, installation and design [in all material respects];

Any goods, such as materials or spare parts, used in the services will be subject to the terms implied by Part 1 of the SGSA in respect of quality, fitness for purpose and conformance with any description or sample (see Drafting note, Implied terms above).

This clause 4.1(d) builds on those implied terms. It sets the standards required for materials used in the services and for the finished product of the services (that is, the deliverables). The second option is designed to be less onerous for the supplier, while still customer friendly.
co-operate with the Customer in all matters relating to the Services, and comply with the Customer's [reasonable] instructions [as to the performance of the Services];

The obligation on the supplier to comply with the customer's instructions is broad. A supplier may object to it, on the basis that it could allow the customer to increase the scope of, or change, the agreed services without allowing the supplier any input on this. The wording in brackets can be used to soften the clause for the supplier.

While this clause 4.1(e) is intended to give the customer some flexibility to modify aspects of the services, ideally the customer should be confident that the description of the services in Schedule 1 captures what the supplier must do, and how it must be done. For tips on drafting a services description, see Drafting note, Services.
provide the Customer with information, advice and training as reasonably required by the Customer to make effective use of the Services;
The supplier may object to clause 4.1(f) and require that any training, for example, is only provided if specifically listed in Schedule 1 and included in the charges in Schedule 2.

maintain all licences, consents and permissions needed to supply the Services in accordance with this agreement[, excluding any licences, consents and permissions that the Customer has agreed in writing to maintain];

hold all Customer Materials in safe custody at its own risk and maintain the Customer Materials in good condition until returned to the Customer, and not dispose of or use the Customer Materials other than in accordance with the Customer's written instructions or authorisations;
take good care of the Customer Equipment in its possession or control;
not do or omit to do anything which may cause the Customer to lose any licence, authority, consent or permission on which it relies for the purposes of conducting its business;
notify the Customer in writing immediately on the occurrence of a change of control of the Supplier; and
Clause 4.1(k) obliges the supplier to tell the customer if it undergoes a change of control and clause 19.3(d) gives the customer a right to terminate on a change of control of the supplier.
[ANY OTHER GENERAL OBLIGATIONS].

[Time is of the essence in relation to the Milestone Dates for the Supplier OR The Supplier shall perform the Services and deliver the Deliverables in accordance with the Milestone Dates.] If the Supplier fails to meet a Milestone Date, then (without prejudice to [the Customer's right to terminate this agreement and] any other rights or remedies that the Customer may have):

the Supplier shall, until the Customer exercises its rights under clause 4.2(d)(i), take all additional steps necessary to perform the Services and deliver the Deliverables as soon as possible after the missed Milestone Date and at no additional cost to the Customer;
the Customer may withhold payment for the delayed Services or Deliverables until the Supplier remedies the delay; [and]

the Supplier shall pay the Customer, as liquidated damages, [[PERCENTAGE]% of the Charges for the delayed Services or Deliverables (Relevant Charges) OR Â£[AMOUNT]] for each [day's OR [PERIOD]'s] delay, [up to a maximum of [[100]% of the Relevant Charges OR Â£[AMOUNT]]; and]
[if the Milestone Date is a Key Milestone Date, or the Supplier fails to perform any Services or deliver any Deliverables within [five] Business Days of the missed Milestone Date,] the Customer may:
refuse to accept any subsequent performance of the delayed Services or supply of the delayed Deliverables which the Supplier attempts to make;
purchase substitute services or deliverables from elsewhere [and reclaim from the Supplier any additional costs it incurs]; and
require the Supplier to immediately refund any sums previously paid by the Customer in respect of the delayed Services or Deliverables.
In English law, it is possible to make time of the essence in relation to contract deadlines. Making time of the essence means that if a deadline is missed, the customer can terminate the agreement.
Clause 4.2 includes two drafting options:

Time of the essence for all milestone dates. This is the most customer-friendly option, but a supplier may object to a single minor delay allowing the customer to terminate the agreement and institute other remedies, such as sourcing replacement services at the supplier's cost. If choosing this option:
select the first option in the first set of brackets in clause 4.2;
include the wording "the Customer's right to terminate this agreement and"; and
omit the wording in brackets in clause 4.2(d).

Cure periods and cumulative lateness before termination rights. An alternative, but still customer-friendly, option is to allow the supplier a chance to remedy lateness, unless the milestone is a key milestone. If the supplier is late on a specified number of occasions, then this amounts to a material breach and the customer can terminate the whole agreement. If choosing this option:
select the second option in the first set of brackets in clause 4.2;
delete the wording "the Customer's right to terminate this agreement and"; and
include the wording in brackets in clause 4.2(d).
Consider whether to limit the repayment required under clause 4.2(d)(iii) to advance payments for services not yet rendered.

Where no dates for performance have been agreed, then the implied term in section 14 of the SGSA would probably take effect, so that the supplier would only have to carry out the services within a reasonable time. As such, it is better to specify the timing for the performance of any obligations.
For further information on time of the essence provisions, see Practice note, Time of the essence.

The Supplier shall pay the liquidated damages under clause 4.2(c) on demand or the Customer may deduct them from its payments to the Supplier. The liquidated damages payable under clause 4.2(c) shall start to accrue on the day after the missed Milestone Date and shall continue to accrue until:
the Supplier completes the performance of the delayed Services or delivers the delayed Deliverables;
the Customer exercises its rights under clause 4.2(d)(i) or terminates this agreement;
the accrued liquidated damages equal the maximum sum set out in clause 4.2(c); or
this agreement expires,
whichever is earlier. The parties confirm that these liquidated damages are reasonable and proportionate to protect the Customer's legitimate interest in timely performance.
Clause 4.2(c) and clause 4.3 allow the customer to recover liquidated damages if the supplier is late in performing the services.
For information on liquidated damages and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Liquidated damages and its drafting notes.

The Supplier shall inform the Customer Contract Manager in writing on completion of each Milestone[, OR or] Deliverable [or [OTHER TRIGGER FOR THE APPROVAL PROCEDURE] (each a Work Item). The Customer [may OR shall] review the Work Item to determine if it conforms [in all material respects] to the requirements of this agreement, including any specifications or acceptance criteria set out in Schedule 1, and provide the Supplier with written approval of the Work Item or a written statement of errors to be corrected.
clause 4.4 to clause 4.8 include an optional procedure for the customer to:
Review each part of the services (including deliverables).
Refuse to pay for services until errors are corrected.
Ultimately source them from elsewhere if the supplier fails to correct the errors.

This type of procedure is generally customer-friendly although we have included optional, pro-supplier drafting in clause 4.5 so that the services will be taken to be approved where the customer starts using them or fails to review them promptly.
Once the customer has approved a part of the services and paid for it, the customer should still be able to claim damages in relation to any defects that later arise.

Whether the procedure in clause 4.4 to clause 4.8 is appropriate will depend on the nature of the services provided. Where they can be performed independently of each other (for example, renovation of multiple different properties or producing marketing materials for separate campaigns), this clause should be suitable as rejection of some elements of the services should not impact on the provision of the remainder. Where the customer wants to make payment of the charges contingent on approval of the services, this clause can also be useful.

However, where each part of the services builds on the previous parts (for example organising, publicising and holding an event), then rejecting one part of the services may make performance of the remainder difficult if not impossible.

Where the same service is provided on an ongoing basis, the customer may decide that service levels are more appropriate than this procedure. With service levels, performance can be measured across a month (for example) and service credits applied to reduce the monthly charges where service levels are not achieved.
For more information, see Practice note, Service levels and service credit schemes in outsourcing.

The Customer shall not unreasonably withhold or delay its approval of a Work Item. [If the Customer puts any Work Item into commercial use or does not inform the Supplier in writing of any errors within [NUMBER] Business Days of being informed that that Work Item is complete under clause 4.3, the Work Item is deemed to be approved by the Customer.] If the Customer approves the Work Item with minor errors, the Supplier shall correct those minor errors promptly [and in any event in accordance with any timescales reasonably specified by the Customer].

If the Customer provides a written statement of errors, the Supplier shall correct the errors in the Work Item at no additional cost to the Customer. The Supplier shall do so within [[25]% of the duration of the original timeframe for provision of the Work Item OR [five] Business Days after receiving the Customer's statement of errors OR the timeframe reasonably specified by the Customer] (Deadline) and inform the Customer Contract Manager in writing when the corrections are complete. The approval process in clause 4.4 and clause 4.5 shall then be repeated. If the Supplier fails to correct the errors by the Deadline, the Customer may (without prejudice to any other rights or remedies it may have):
require the Supplier to repeat the process to correct errors in this clause 4.6;

approve the Work Item subject to [a reasonable deduction from the Charges to reflect the errors in the Work Item and the delays caused by the Work Item not being compliant when first completed OR any conditions that the Customer reasonably determines [provided that the conditions may not, without the Supplier's prior written consent, increase its obligations or restrict its rights or remedies under this agreement]. If all the relevant conditions have not been met within the period specified by the Customer, the Customer may exercise its rights in clause 4.6(c) and clause 4.7]; or
finally refuse to approve the Work Item and refuse any subsequent performance which the Supplier attempts to make.
If the Customer finally refuses to approve a Work Item under clause 4.6(c), it may (without prejudice to any other rights or remedies it may have) do one or more of the following:
refuse to pay for the Work Item and require the Supplier to immediately refund any sums previously paid to the Supplier for that Work Item; and
purchase substitute services or deliverables from elsewhere [and reclaim from the Supplier any additional costs it incurs].

head.headtext: Remedies for rejecting non-compliant services (optional clause)

para.paratext: Under clause 4.7, the customer does not have to pay for services it does not approve and can purchase substitute services elsewhere with any additional costs of doing so recoverable. There is also an optional termination right in Drafting note, Termination for missed milestone dates (optional clause).

Approval by the Customer of any Work Item does not mean that the Customer has varied or waived its requirements for any part of the Services. Approval is without prejudice to any rights or remedies of the Customer under the terms of this agreement or in law.

All Supplier property, including Supplier Equipment, shall remain at the sole risk and responsibility of the Supplier, except that the Customer shall be liable for damage to any of the Supplier's property located on the Customer's premises [(with the Customer's prior written consent)] which is due to the negligent act or omission of the Customer.
This clause 5 requires the supplier to provide suitable personnel to perform the services and ensure key individuals service the customer.
The Supplier shall ensure that the Supplier Personnel:
have suitable skills and experience to enable them to perform the tasks assigned to them [and have been adequately trained in the provision of the Services];

hold all licences, permits, visas and consents required for the proper performance of this agreement, including the right to work in all relevant jurisdictions, and have been properly screened and vetted by the Supplier to ensure they are fit for the positions that they are in;

observe all health and safety rules and regulations and all reasonable security requirements that apply from time to time at the Customer's premises they access [and that have been communicated to the Supplier under clause 6.1(e)]; and
are in sufficient number to enable the Supplier to fulfil its obligations under this agreement.

The quality of the supplier's services depends on the people it uses to perform them. The customer will want the supplier to make sure the right volume of people, with the right mix of skills, are used to provide the services.

With clause 5.1(c), the customer should be aware that the supplier may want to review these rules and requirements before committing to them and may also want the right to increase its charges if there is a change which impacts on its costs.

For a clause requiring compliance with the customer's security policy and dealing with how it may be changed and the cost implications of this, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: shorter form: clause 25.
For a more detailed example of a clause requiring compliance with health and safety laws and policies, see Standard document, Services agreement for use by public sector bodies: clause 6.2.

If the Customer (acting reasonably) believes that any Supplier Person is not performing the Services properly or effectively or is disruptive to the Customer's business, the Customer may require the Supplier to remove that Supplier Person from the Customer's account and ensure they cease to be involved in the Services. The Supplier shall promptly do so at its cost and without [any material] interruption to the Services.
The supplier may object to this optional clause 5.2 allowing the customer to remove supplier personnel from the services.
The customer could soften the clause by including a duty for the customer to consider any representations from the supplier as to why someone should not be removed.
The Supplier shall:
use the Key Personnel in the provision of the Services [and procure that the Key Personnel spend the percentage of their working hours set out in Schedule 3 in the provision of the Services];

promptly inform the Customer of the absence (or the anticipated absence) of any of the Key Personnel [(other than for short-term absences of [two] weeks or less)] and, if required by the Customer, provide a suitably qualified, temporary replacement for that individual;
[not remove or replace OR use its [best OR reasonable] endeavours not to remove or replace] any Key Personnel during the Term provided that the Supplier may do so if:
[requested to do so by the Customer under clause 5.2;]
the person is on maternity leave, paternity leave, shared parental leave, or long-term sick leave;
the person is suspended for misconduct;
[the element of the Services in respect of which the Key Person was engaged has been completed [to the Customer's reasonable satisfaction];]
the person [resigns from their employment with the Supplier or] ceases to be employed by the Supplier; or
the Supplier obtains the prior [written] approval of the Customer [(not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)];

[obtain the prior [written] approval of the Customer [(approval not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)] to any replacement for a Key Personnel member OR ensure that any replacement for a Key Personnel member has the qualifications and experience to carry out the tasks assigned to the Key Personnel member being replaced];
[use [all] reasonable endeavours to] ensure that the role of each of its Key Personnel is not vacant (in terms of a permanent representative) for more than [ten] Business Days]; and

bear all costs and expenses associated with the appointment, removal or replacement of Key Personnel, including time spent by any replacement familiarising themselves with the Supplier's duties under this agreement.

Key personnel is defined to include the individuals identified (by both name and job title) as key personnel in Schedule 3. Providing for these individuals to be identified in the schedule means that the customer approves their appointment. The impact of an individual being identified as key personnel is that the supplier must:
Ensure that the key personnel are used in providing the services and spend all or a minimum amount of their time on them.
Notify the customer of their absence (and, if so required, provide a replacement for them).
Try to ensure they continue to provide the services throughout the term of the agreement.
Allow the customer to approve replacements to key personnel if the first option in clause 5.3(d) is selected.
Whether the supplier accepts key personnel provisions depends on factors such as:

The nature of the services. If the services are general in nature, the supplier may be unable to make key personnel exclusively available for the customer as it may be providing similar services to other customers. If the services are bespoke to the customer, then the supplier may be able to meet this requirement as it is unlikely that another customer will be seeking those exact same services.

The importance of the services to the customer. If the services are critical to the operation of the customer's business, the customer may insist on including this clause to ensure that the supplier personnel are not distracted by other customers that they are working for. If the services are particularly confidential, the customer may not want key supplier staff servicing other customers as it could increase the chances of confidential information being leaked. If the customer is unable to negotiate the exclusive use of key personnel, it may be able to include restrictions on specific customer staff from working for the customer's competitors (see Standard clause, Exclusive purchasing and supply clause: long form: clause 1.6).

The organisational structure of the supplier. The supplier may have insufficient resources to meet these requirements, or the employees involved with providing the services may work across more than one business unit within its business.
Clause 5.3(c) includes various options that allow the customer to dilute these requirements for a supplier unwilling to accept them.

During the Term, the Supplier shall provide, within [NUMBER] days of the Customer's request, any information reasonably requested by the Customer relating to the way in which the Services are organised, including:
the number of Supplier Personnel engaged in providing the Services;
the [average weekly] percentage of their working hours spent by each Supplier Person on the Services; and
a description of the nature of work undertaken by each Supplier Person.

The information provided under clause 5.4 should help the customer understand how the supplier resources the services. That information can be useful in transitioning services to a new supplier or understanding if TUPE will be applicable on termination.
Each party shall comply with its obligations in Schedule 6.
For more information, see Drafting note, Transfer of employees under TUPE above and the integrated drafting notes at Schedule 6.

The supplier usually needs a degree of co-operation from the customer to provide the services. As this is a pro-customer agreement, the customer's obligations are relatively few and general in nature. They include basic commitments about co-operation, access and information.
The Customer shall:
co-operate with the Supplier in all matters relating to the Services;

provide access to the Customer's premises and other facilities as may reasonably be requested by the Supplier[, and agreed with the Customer [in writing] in advance,] for the purposes of the Services;

Clause 6.1(b) obliges the customer to provide access to its premises and facilities. It is expressed in general terms, but if the services require specific facilities which are unusual but necessary (for example, a dedicated telephone line or access for large vehicles at any time of the day or night), these should be set out in the agreement.
provide to the Supplier all documents, information, items and materials required under Schedule 1 [or otherwise reasonably required by the Supplier for the purpose of providing the Services];
The wording in brackets can be used where the parties cannot be certain, at the outset, which materials will be needed.

The supplier may want to include a provision that the customer materials are provided by a deadline and that they are accurate and complete (see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 5). From the customer's perspective, obligations like this should be qualified, for example, by reference to "reasonable endeavours".
For information on best and reasonable endeavours, see Practice note, Best or reasonable endeavours?.
provide the Customer Equipment to the Supplier by the dates and in the manner prescribed in Schedule 1;

inform the Supplier of all health and safety and security requirements that apply from time to time at [any of] the Customer's premises which the Supplier will require access to. [The Customer's requirements as at the Effective Date are set out in Schedule 4]; and
[ANY OTHER RELEVANT OBLIGATIONS].
Consider whether it is sensible for the customer to offer further obligations, such as:
Providing timely approvals or feedback.
Taking care of the supplier's equipment.
Obtaining and maintaining appropriate licences and consents to enable the supplier to provide the services.

Not soliciting the supplier's staff for employment by the customer. For an example of this clause and information on it, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 7 and its drafting notes.
The Supplier cannot rely on the Customer's breach of this agreement to excuse any failure in the Supplier's performance unless:
the Supplier promptly notifies the Customer in writing [and in reasonable detail] of the Customer breach and its effect or anticipated effect on the Services;
the obligations that the Supplier cannot perform are directly [and materially] impacted by the Customer's breach; and
the Supplier uses all reasonable endeavours to continue to provide the affected obligations in accordance with this agreement.

When things start to go wrong, the first manifestation of this is often delay, and the supplier will often try and blame the customer. This clause 6.2 is intended to make the supplier's right to relief contingent on notifying the customer of the issue and taking steps to mitigate its effects.

Relief only applies to obligations directly impacted by the customer's breach. There is optional wording so that supplier performance needs to be materially impacted. As this is customer-friendly, the customer should expect push back from the supplier if including this.
The Supplier cannot rely on a notice given under clause 6.2(a) in respect of any failure in the Supplier's performance which occurs before the Customer's receipt of that notice.
Clause 6.3 restricts the supplier's ability to excuse its own poor performance by pointing to a long-past failure by the customer which the supplier did not comment on at the time.

Some suppliers may push back on this clause, arguing that it may not be operationally possible to notify the customer straight away of a relief event and that it would be unreasonable to deny the supplier relief in these circumstances. Given the obligation in clause 6.2(a) to notify the customer "promptly" of any relief event, the customer may decide that this clause can be omitted.

The Customer may challenge any notice received from the Supplier under clause 6.2(a) if it believes, in its reasonable opinion, that the breach notified to it should not have [an OR a material] adverse effect on the Supplier performing its obligations in accordance with this agreement. Any resulting dispute regarding the occurrence or impact of the notified breach may be referred by either party for resolution in accordance with clause 34. Any failure by the Customer to challenge a notice from the Supplier under clause 6.2(a) does not mean that the Customer accepts that it is in breach or that any breach excuses any failure in the Supplier's performance.

Clause 7 sets out the process to request a change to the scope or execution of the services. The process is relatively customer friendly as it obliges the supplier to engage with customer change requests. For a more supplier-friendly change control clause that obliges the customer to accept supplier change requests in certain circumstances, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 9.
The procedure in this clause is straightforward and should be suitable where the services are not too complex.

Where the likelihood of significant change to the services is low (for example, because the term of the agreement is short), the parties may decide that a change control procedure is not necessary. If that is the case, delete this clause.

For more complex services or if the agreement has a long term, "change" may need to be dealt with more comprehensively. Of particular relevance is whether the services and the charges are defined in such a way as to accommodate a degree of change during the life of the agreement. For example, can the price for any particular level of usage of the services be ascertained from Schedule 2? Or would any change in usage always require reference to this procedure?
For a more detailed change control procedure, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement shorter form: Schedule 13.

The parties may also want to agree a template change control note, which can be attached as a schedule to the agreement. In some organisations, change requests will be prepared and managed by non-legal staff (commercial managers or operational personnel), so having a clear template may make the process more efficient. It would also ensure consistency across all change control notes, making it easier to keep track of all the changes made during the term of the agreement.
For a change control note template, see Standard clause, Change control.

Either party may submit a written request for Change to the other party in accordance with this clause 7, but no proposed Change will come into effect until a Change Control Note has been signed by the authorised representatives of both parties.
If the Customer wishes to make a Change:
the Customer shall submit a written request to the Supplier, providing as much detail as is reasonably necessary to enable the Supplier to prepare the draft Change Control Note; and
the Supplier shall, within [NUMBER] Business Days of receiving the Customer's request at clause 7.2(a), provide a Change Control Note to the Customer.
If the Supplier wishes to make a Change, it shall send a Change Control Note to the Customer.
A Change Control Note must contain sufficient information to enable the Customer to assess the Change, including as a minimum:
the title of the Change;
a description of the Change;
details of the effect of the proposed Change on:
the Services;
the Charges;
the timetable for the Services; and
any other term of this agreement.
The Supplier may only reject a request for Change from the Customer under clause 7.2(a) if the Supplier can demonstrate to the Customer's reasonable satisfaction that:
the proposed Change would require this agreement to be delivered in a way that infringes any Applicable Law; or
it does not have the technical skill or capacity to implement the proposed Change.
If the parties:
agree to the terms of a Change Control Note, they shall sign it and that Change Control Note will amend this agreement; or
are unable to agree a Change Control Note, either party may require the disagreement to be dealt with in accordance with clause 34.
[Each party bears its own costs in relation to compliance with the procedure in this clause 7.

The Supplier may charge for the time it spends on preparing and negotiating Change Control Notes where the Customer has requested the Change under clause 7.2(a). The Supplier shall charge for its time on a time and materials basis at the Supplier's daily rates specified in Schedule 2.]

The first option clarifies that neither party can charge the other for compliance with change control. If the customer is willing to pay for the supplier's time spent in dealing with change requests which the customer originates, use the second option.
There are several options for pricing services agreements, including:
Time and materials.
Fixed price.

Hybrid arrangements such as ceiling pricing (time and materials fixed up to an agreed level) and staged pricing, with one or more stages being based on time and materials and one or more other stages on a fixed price.
This clause 8 assumes that the parties will agree the pricing and payment terms for the services upfront.
Clause 8.2 provides some detail on how the supplier's rates work, which should be amended to reflect the actual position (and could alternatively be set out in Schedule 2).

A time and materials fee approach can benefit the customer so that it only pays for work actually done. However, it can be risky because the customer does not have control over the total price for the services. If the supplier is charging on a time and materials basis, consider whether to include a cap on the total fees that can be charged.

If payment is linked to milestones, draft the milestones (which could be set out in Schedule 1 or Schedule 2) so as to minimise disputes over whether a milestone has been achieved (and subsequently, whether payment is due).
When drafting milestone provisions for the customer:
Make it as clear as possible what achievement involves, and ensure that general statements are broken down into specific detail.

Make sure that it is clear when a milestone is achieved, so that payment is triggered. A customer may want the trigger for payment to be completion of the milestone to the customer's satisfaction. The supplier will at least want to stipulate "reasonable" satisfaction and is likely to push for more objective criteria.

If appropriate to the services, consider making invoicing and payment contingent on services being approved or accepted (see Drafting note, Reviewing results of services (optional clause)). For an example of a detailed acceptance testing process, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: long form: clause 8.

As this is a pro-customer agreement, there is no clause permitting the supplier to increase the charges unilaterally. From a negotiating perspective, the customer may not want to offer this type of clause in the initial draft provided to the supplier, but note that the supplier may ask for it to be included.
For a clause which permits the supplier to increase the charges, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 10.4.
In consideration of the provision of the Services by the Supplier, the Customer shall pay the Charges.
Where the Charges are calculated on a time and materials basis:
the Supplier's fee rates for each individual person are set out in Schedule 2;
daily fee rates are calculated on the basis of an eight-hour day, worked during Business Hours; [and]

the Supplier shall not be entitled to charge on a pro rata basis for part days worked by the Supplier Personnel during Business Hours, unless it has the Customer's prior written consent to do so; [and]

head.headtext: Less than a day's work (optional clause)

para.paratext: Clause 8.2(c) ensures the supplier cannot charge where it works less than a day without the customer's approval.

if the Customer has agreed in writing in advance, the Supplier may charge for specific work outside Business Hours by Supplier Personnel at the overtime rates set out in Schedule 2[, pro-rated to reflect the hours worked]. The Supplier may not charge for work done outside Business Hours in any other circumstances; and
This clause 8.2(d) includes optional wording so that the customer can pre-approve overtime. While this could be onerous to administer, in practice the customer is free to give a wide permission.
the Supplier shall ensure that all Supplier Personnel complete time sheets to record time spent on the Services, and the Supplier shall indicate the time spent per individual in its invoices.
The Customer shall reimburse the Supplier for the following costs and expenses which are excluded from the Charges:
the cost of hotel, subsistence, travelling and any other ancillary expenses reasonably incurred by the Supplier Personnel in connection with the Services, provided that:

the Supplier obtains the Customer's prior written approval before incurring [any expenses OR any individual expense item exceeding Â£[AMOUNT] OR any expenses over Â£[AMOUNT] in any calendar month]; [and]
any expenses are incurred in accordance with the Customer's expenses policy, as set out in Schedule 4 and updated from time to time on written notice to the Supplier; and

Receiving late invoices long after work has been done can create an administrative burden for the customer to reconcile, particularly if it has closed the books on a financial year.

However, the customer should bear in mind that the courts may be reluctant to deny the supplier any payment purely on the basis that it has invoiced late. For more information, see Practice note, Invoices in commercial contracts: common issues: Late invoicing and waiver of debt.

This clause 8.11 allows the supplier to charge interest for late payment by the customer.

Suppliers usually expect to have a right to charge interest where the customer is late paying. It can also be in the customer's interests to include a late payment interest clause so that it displaces the higher, statutory interest rate that would otherwise apply under the Late Payment of Commercial Debts (Interest) Act 1998.

The second option in this clause is pro-customer wording as it gives the customer time to cure the late payment before the supplier can charge late payment interest. If the customer uses this option, it should avoid making the cure period so long that the clause fails to provide a substantial remedy for the supplier and therefore statutory interest applies. All sums payable to the Supplier under this agreement are exclusive of VAT, and the Customer shall, in addition, pay an amount equal to any VAT chargeable on those sums subject to receipt of a valid VAT invoice.

A customer in a strong bargaining position may leave this clause out so that the charges are deemed to be inclusive of VAT. However, most b2b suppliers price their services on a VAT-exclusive basis and the customer is usually responsible for paying VAT in addition to the supplier's fees.

The Customer may, at any time[, without notice to the Supplier,] set off any liability of the Supplier to the Customer against any liability of the Customer to the Supplier, whether either liability is present or future, liquidated or unliquidated, and whether or not either liability arises under this agreement. If the liabilities to be set off are expressed in different currencies, the Customer may convert either liability at a market rate of exchange for the purpose of set-off. Any exercise by the Customer of its rights under this clause shall not limit or affect any other rights or remedies available to it under this agreement or otherwise.
For a discussion on set-off clauses, see the integrated drafting notes to Standard clause, Set-off.

This optional clause 9 requires the supplier to maintain records and allow the customer and its auditors to audit the supplier to check it is charging the customer accurately and, optionally, complying with its other contractual obligations. The customer will be particularly keen to audit the supplier's charges where the supplier is working on a time and materials or similar variable basis, or incurring significant pass-through costs.

If the services are high value and complex, a limited audit right in relation to the charges only is unlikely to be enough for the customer. In this scenario, the customer usually wants a wide audit clause to enable it to:
Examine the supplier's performance of the services, as well as the charges for them.
Identify suspected fraud.
Verify the supplier's compliance with the customer's mandatory policies as required by clause 12.
Verify that the supplier is handling the customer's data in a compliant manner.

If the services are relatively simple or low value, or charged on a flat fee or fixed price basis. the supplier may challenge the need for an audit clause. The customer would argue that audit rights are the only way to accurately check that the supplier is complying with the agreement. If the supplier has done so, there should be no issue with the supplier being open to audits.
If the supplier agrees to an audit provision, it usually wants the customer's audit rights to be subject to:
A requirement that audits be performed during normal business hours and on reasonable prior notice.
A limitation on the frequency of audits.
Confidentiality restrictions.

This audit clause includes optional wording for these restrictions. The customer may want to use this wording to placate a supplier who objects to audit rights. Adapt the clause for any other limitations on audit rights (for example, suppliers sometimes only allow audits to be carried out by professional third party auditors).
The audit clause also sets out:
Which party bears the costs of audits.
The consequences of what happens if the audit reveals non-compliance.
For more information on audit clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Audit.

There are generally three categories of material used and provided in connection with services, as set out below. The results of the services (namely, the deliverables) are likely to contain elements from at least two of these categories:

Materials owned by each party which are or have been developed independently of the services. Each party will want to retain ownership of these background materials but may need to license them to the other party as necessary for the provision or receipt of the services. From the customer's perspective, these materials might be plans, specifications or branding that the supplier needs for the services. From the supplier's perspective, these might be software and other materials it uses with (and licenses to) all its clients.

Materials owned by a third party and supplied either by the customer to the supplier, or by the supplier to the customer. Each party may need to supply third party materials to the other. For example, the supplier may need to provide some third party software or the customer may need to supply research data licensed from third parties to the supplier. Normally the party providing the third party-owned material will be responsible for procuring a licence to enable the other party to use it as necessary. In some cases (for example, where the supplier is using off-the-shelf software), it might make more sense for the customer to acquire a licence directly from the licensor. If so, this would need to be specifically addressed in the agreement.

Materials created by the supplier specifically for the customer in the provision of the services. These can either be licensed by the supplier to the customer on a non-exclusive basis or assigned to the customer so that the customer owns them. The customer usually wants to own the IPRs in all deliverables created for it.

In practice, it may not be obvious which parts of a deliverable have been specifically developed for the customer (and so are being assigned to the customer) and which are the supplier's pre-existing materials or third party materials (and are merely being licensed). The customer may want to seek clarity on this, perhaps requiring that materials not being assigned cannot be included in a deliverable without the customer's prior approval.
The benefits for the customer of owning the IPRs in materials developed for it are:
Exclusivity. The customer can prevent others from using the deliverables it has paid for and from which it expects to gain a competitive advantage.
Enforcement. The customer has the right to enforce the relevant IPRs.

However, where exclusivity is not an issue and the supplier's business model is such that improvements made for one client are shared with all clients, then it may be appropriate for the customer to just receive a non-exclusive licence. Where the supplier is willing to give the customer a limited period of exclusivity, this could be achieved by granting an exclusive licence which later becomes non-exclusive.
Clause 10 offers two options:

Licence of IPR in deliverables. The supplier retains ownership of all IPRs in the deliverables (excluding any customer materials, ownership of which is retained by the customer) (see clause 10.2). The supplier grants the customer a non-exclusive licence of the IPRs which it owns in the deliverables. Options for the duration of the licence and whether sub-licensing is permitted are included in square brackets (see clause 10.3 and clause 10.4).

Assignment of IPR in deliverables. The supplier assigns ownership of the IPRs in the deliverables to the customer (see clause 10.6). There is optional drafting so that the supplier retains ownership of its proprietary materials and licenses the customer to use them instead of assigning them (see clause 10.7). The customer licenses the supplier to use the deliverables that are assigned to the customer (see clause 10.9). The supplier needs to continue to use those materials to service the customer.

With each of these options, there is optional drafting (see clause 10.5 and clause 10.8), which provides for the inclusion in the deliverables of third party-owned materials (such as music, images or off-the-shelf software). These materials are often only available on standard licence terms and so it may not be possible to assign them to the customer or license them on the same terms as the supplier's proprietary materials. There is drafting so that third party materials cannot be included in the deliverables without the customer's approval of the licence terms.
There are benefits to this drafting for both parties:

The supplier can (assuming it obtains customer approval) use third party materials that cannot be assigned to the customer or licensed on a perpetual or royalty-free basis. For example, this may be the case where the supplier wants to use software or data that is only licensed on standard terms for a limited period and for a fee.
For the customer, the clause allows it to retain a degree of control over the inclusion of any third party IPRs in the deliverables.

The supplier warrants to the customer that the deliverables do not infringe any third party's IPRs (see clause 16.4(a)) and indemnifies the customer against any third party claims if they do (see clause 16.5(a)).

The Customer and its licensors shall retain ownership of all Intellectual Property Rights in the Customer Materials. The Customer grants to the Supplier a non-exclusive, royalty-free, non-transferable (except in accordance with clause 22.1) licence to use, copy and modify the Customer Materials during the Term for the sole purpose of providing the Services to the Customer in accordance with this agreement. The Supplier cannot sublicense the Customer Materials to any third party [(other than permitted subcontractors under clause 22)] without the Customer's prior written consent.

Supplier materials are defined as materials created before this agreement started or independently of this agreement by the supplier or its suppliers. The supplier may argue that these materials should not be assigned to the customer because they have been and will be used for the benefit of other customers. In this case, it is reasonable to exclude supplier materials from the assignment of IPRs in the deliverables. These items will continue to be owned by the supplier but the supplier licences the customer to use them so that the customer can fully benefit from the deliverables (see clause 10.7).

If it is important to the customer to receive an assignment of and own all or at least the key parts of the deliverables (and so benefit from the exclusive rights ownership brings), the customer may want to pre-approve the inclusion of any supplier materials in the deliverables. There is optional wording for this in clause 10.7.
Alternative approaches include:
Identifying the supplier materials pre-contract and listing them in a schedule, so that the customer knows which parts of the deliverables it will own from the beginning.
The supplier agreeing not to license the supplier materials to the customer's competitors for a specified period.

Third party materials are defined as materials owned by a third party but not an affiliate of the supplier or a subcontractor. These are likely to be off-the-shelf materials that the third party licenses to multiple customers and are not made available for assignment to the customer. If the customer is, in principle, willing to allow the inclusion of third party materials in the deliverables, it should make their inclusion and the terms on which they are licensed subject to the customer's approval (see Drafting note, Supplier licence of third party materials (optional clause)).

If there are any supplier materials that the supplier cannot license perpetually (for example, because they are proprietary tools that can only be used by existing customers), those items could be carved out from the perpetual licence to the customer and licensed only during the term of this agreement.

Both parties can benefit from appointing contract managers who:
Manage the overall relationship between the parties.
Act as a first point of contact in case of a problem, with the aim of resolving the problem before it rises to the level of a dispute or breach.
Have authority to legally bind the parties regarding some aspects of the services, including solutions to problems.
The customer may want the right to approve the supplier's contract manager, in which case it will seek to include the second set of optional language in clause 11.3.
Clause 11.4 and clause 11.5 contain optional wording to prevent the supplier from acting on any instructions that do not come from a customer contract manager.
Clause 11.6 and clause 11.7 include basic governance drafting around review meetings and transparency.
Clause 11.8 is pro-customer wording that requires the supplier to resolve an issue even where the issue may have been caused by the customer.
For a more comprehensive governance clause, see Standard clause, Governance.

The customer usually requires the supplier to comply with relevant laws and the customer's supply chain policies. These policies typically reflect the customer's own legal obligations, such as in relation to anti-bribery or data protection, where it may be required to flow down obligations to its suppliers. Other policies, such as a general supplier code of conduct or an environmental, social and governance policy, may set out the behaviours and minimum standards expected by the customer from its suppliers. Failure to adhere to those standards could cause reputational as well as legal harm to the customer.
If the supplier will be using AI to perform the services, the customer may want to specify that the supplier complies with policies and procedures to:
Use AI responsibly.
Help establish ownership of IPRs in AI outputs and avoid the risk of third-party IPR infringement.

If the customer does not have a standalone AI policy, consider including AI-specific requirements in a general supplier code of conduct. For example, see Standard document, Supplier code of conduct (UK): section 5 (Artificial intelligence (AI)).
For more information on this clause 12, see Drafting note, Supply chain issues and the drafting notes to Standard clause, Compliance with laws and policies.
In performing its obligations under this agreement, the Supplier shall comply with:
all Applicable Laws; and

The term "Applicable Laws" is defined to include all legislation in force from time to time, not just legislation that is in force when the agreement is signed. The supplier is therefore obliged to adapt to and comply with changes in law during the agreement as part of its obligations. Apart from the change control procedure in clause 7, there is no mechanism for the supplier to increase its charges to comply with changes in law.
the Mandatory Policies.

The Customer shall give the Supplier not less than [NUMBER] days' notice of any change to the Mandatory Policies, including the introduction of any new Mandatory Policy, before the change takes effect. The Supplier shall comply with the change from the date it takes effect [provided that if any change to the Mandatory Policies would materially increase the Supplier's obligations or costs under this agreement, the Supplier may, within [NUMBER] days of the Customer's notice, [request a proportionate increase to the Charges in accordance with the procedure in clause 7 OR notify the Customer that it objects to the change in which case the change shall not take effect with regard to the Supplier]. [The Supplier cannot exercise its rights under this clause 12.2 where the change to the Mandatory Policies reflects a change in Applicable Law that:
generally affects the supply of services similar to the Services; or
would have been reasonably foreseeable on the Effective Date by an experienced supplier performing services similar to the Services.]

The supplier may not accept that the customer can change policies at any time on notice to the supplier, introducing new obligations unilaterally. To soften the clause for the supplier, the customer could include optional clause 12.2 which requires the customer to give a period of notice before changes take effect.

The first set of optional wording allows the supplier to request an increase in the charges if the policy change will materially increase its obligations or costs. The second set of optional wording allows the supplier to object to the change but also allows the customer to terminate if the supplier does so. The final sentence is optional wording that obliges the supplier to accept the policy change where it reflects changes in law applicable to suppliers in a similar position or that were reasonably foreseeable.
The Supplier warrants and represents that neither it, nor to the best of its knowledge any of the Supplier Personnel or any of its suppliers involved in performing the Services (Associated Persons):
has committed an offence under any of the Relevant Requirements; or

has been or is the subject of any investigation, inquiry, or enforcement proceedings by any governmental, administrative, or regulatory body regarding any offence or alleged offence under any of the Relevant Requirements.

Clause 12.3 to clause 12.9 include additional, optional obligations that the customer may want to impose on the supplier in relation to specific laws under which the customer may be responsible for the actions of the supplier, such as laws against bribery and human trafficking (see Drafting note, Supply chain issues).
There is also an optional indemnity in clause 16.5 under which the supplier indemnifies the customer if its breach of these specific laws causes the customer loss.
For a range of more detailed supply chain compliance clauses, see Supply chain compliance toolkit: Specific compliance issues.

The Supplier shall promptly notify the Customer if, at any time during the Term, its circumstances, knowledge, or awareness changes such that it would not be able to repeat the warranties set out in clause 12.3 at the relevant time.

The Supplier shall not do or omit to do any act which would cause the Customer to contravene any of the Relevant Requirements or otherwise incur any liability in relation to the Relevant Requirements.

The Supplier shall maintain and enforce its own policies and procedures which are adequate to ensure compliance with the Relevant Requirements. The Supplier shall ensure that its subcontractors are required to comply with [terms that are at least as onerous as those in this clause 12 OR policies and procedures which are adequate to ensure compliance with the Relevant Requirements]. The Supplier shall be directly liable to the Customer for any failure to do so by any of those subcontractors.

The first option in this clause 12.6 requires the supplier to ensure that its subcontractors comply with equivalent terms. This is the best outcome for the customer but the most difficult for the supplier. The supplier may already have terms in place with its subcontractors and may be unable to amend them to comply with this requirement.

The second option is easier for the supplier to comply with. Many of its subcontractors should already have policies and procedures in place to ensure they do not breach laws against bribery, human trafficking or fraud.
The Supplier shall immediately notify the Customer if it has reason to believe that it or any of its Associated Persons is in receipt of a request or demand:
for any undue financial or other advantage of any kind; or
to commit a fraud offence within the meaning of section 199(6) of the Economic Crime and Corporate Transparency Act 2023,
in connection with the performance of this agreement.

The Supplier shall co-operate with and provide reasonable assistance to the Customer, at the Customer's [reasonable] cost, to enable the Customer to investigate, or respond to any requests from a governmental, administrative, or regulatory body to investigate, an alleged offence under any of the Relevant Requirements.

Within [NUMBER] months of the Effective Date, and annually thereafter, the Supplier shall provide the Customer with a written statement, signed by an officer of the Supplier, certifying compliance with the Relevant Requirements by the Supplier and all its Associated Persons [to the best of its knowledge].

Some customers like to have the comfort of an annual compliance statement from their suppliers. To shorten the drafting and make it less onerous for the supplier, the customer could remove this clause 12.9 and rely solely on the supplier's positive duty to flag issues in clause 12.4.
Many services agreements involve the supplier processing personal data in connection with supplying the services.
The customer could face significant financial and reputational damage if the supplier 's failings result in unauthorised access to personal data or other breaches of data protection laws.
It is assumed for the purposes of this agreement that:
Both parties are subject to the UK GDPR and may also be subject to the EU GDPR.
The supplier will process personal data in connection with the provision of the services to the customer, and in particular:
