the supplier will process personal data as a processor, on behalf of the customer, in respect of certain processing activities to be specified in paragraph 1 of Schedule 5;
the supplier may process personal data as an independent controller in respect of certain processing activities to be specified in paragraph 2 of Schedule 5; and
the supplier may process personal data as a joint controller in respect of certain processing activities to be specified in paragraph 3 of Schedule 5.
If any of these processing activities will not take place, clause 13.3 and Schedule 5 should be amended accordingly.
The customer will not act as a processor on behalf of the supplier at any point. This is likely to be the case for most types of supply relationships.
The processing of personal data does not require any approval from a regulator nor is it subject to any ongoing regulatory compliance regime other than data protection compliance.

There is a financial cap on data processing breaches that is separate from, and in addition to, the contract's overall liability cap (see clause 18.3(b)). As this is a pro-customer agreement, there is also an optional indemnity from the supplier (see clause 16.5(c)).
Certain provisions in this clause 13 could overlap with other clauses in the agreement. For instance:

The confidentiality requirements in clause 13.7(c) and the general confidentiality provisions in clause 14. Consider whether the definition of "Confidential Information" should include "Customer Personal Data" and "Shared Personal Data".
The sub-processing requirements in clause 13.8 and the general subcontracting provisions at clause 22.

The supplier's obligation to delete or return the personal data on termination or expiry of the agreement in clause 13.7(f) and the supplier's general obligation on termination or expiry in relation to returning the customer's materials and deliverables in clause 20.1.
The audit provisions in clause 13.7(g) and the general audit rights in clause 9.
Check that the approach taken in this clause 13 is consistent with the other clauses in this agreement.

The parties could decide to address related issues within the same clause. For example, the sub-processing provisions could be included in the general subcontracting clause. However, the parties may find it easier if all data processing-related provisions are in the same clause, as opposed to being dotted throughout the agreement.
The drafting in this clause 13 is partly based on the following standard clauses which provide background information and further drafting if necessary:
Data processing clauses (UK).
Personal data sharing clauses (controller to controller, short-form) (UK).
Personal data processing clauses for IT agreements (UK) (pro-customer).

For the purposes of this clause 13, the terms Commissioner, controller, data subject, personal data, personal data breach, processor and processing shall have the meaning given to them in Applicable Data Protection Law.

Each party shall comply with all Applicable Data Protection Laws in its processing of personal data under or in connection with this agreement. This clause 13 is in addition to, and does not relieve, remove or replace, a party's obligations or rights under Applicable Data Protection Laws.
The parties have determined that, for the purposes of Applicable Data Protection Laws:
the Supplier shall process the personal data set out in paragraph 1 of Schedule 5 as a processor on behalf of the Customer[; and OR .]
the Supplier and Customer shall act as independent controllers in respect of the personal data and processing activities set out in paragraph 2 of Schedule 5[; and OR .]
the Supplier and Customer shall act as joint controllers in respect of the personal data and processing activities set out in paragraph 3 of Schedule 5.
Without prejudice to clause 13.2, where one party (Data Discloser) shares personal data with the other party (Data Recipient) as controllers (Shared Personal Data), the Data Recipient shall:
only process the Shared Personal Data for the purposes set out in Schedule 5 or otherwise agreed in writing by the parties (Agreed Purposes); and
not retain or process the Shared Personal Data for longer than is necessary to carry out the Agreed Purposes.
Without prejudice to clause 13.2, each party shall:
ensure that it has all necessary notices and lawful bases in place to process the Shared Personal Data for the Agreed Purposes;
give full information to any data subject whose Shared Personal Data may be processed under this agreement of the nature of that processing;

ensure that it has in place appropriate technical and organisational measures to protect against unauthorised or unlawful processing of Shared Personal Data and against accidental loss or destruction of, or damage to, Shared Personal Data; and
provide reasonable assistance to the other party in complying with Applicable Data Protection Laws in relation to the Shared Personal Data, including by:
promptly informing the other party about the receipt of any data subject rights request that relates to the other party's processing;
providing the other party with reasonable assistance in complying with any data subject rights request; and

notifying the other party without undue delay on becoming aware of any personal data breach in relation to the Shared Personal Data [and doing all things reasonably necessary to assist the other party in mitigating the effects of the personal data breach].
Use optional clause 13.4 and clause 13.5 if the parties will be sharing any data as independent controllers or joint controllers.
To ensure that shared personal data is kept confidential under clause 14, include shared personal data within the definition of Confidential Information.
For comprehensive data sharing provisions, see Standard documents:
Data sharing agreement (controller to controller) (UK).
Data sharing agreement (joint controllers) (UK).

In relation to the Customer Personal Data, paragraph 1 of Schedule 5 sets out the scope, nature and purpose of processing by the Supplier, the duration of the processing and the types of personal data and categories of data subject.
Without prejudice to clause 13.2, the Supplier shall, in relation to Customer Personal Data:

process that Customer Personal Data only on the documented written instructions of the Customer, which are set out in paragraph 1 of Schedule 5, unless the Supplier is required by Applicable Laws to otherwise process that Customer Personal Data. Where the Supplier is relying on Applicable Laws as the basis for processing Customer Personal Data, the Supplier shall promptly notify the Customer of this before performing the processing unless prohibited from doing so by those Applicable Laws. The Supplier shall immediately inform the Customer if, in the opinion of the Supplier, the instructions of the Customer infringe Applicable Data Protection Laws;

ensure that it has in place appropriate technical and organisational measures[, including those in paragraph 1.1(g) of Schedule 5,] to protect against unauthorised or unlawful processing of Customer Personal Data and against its accidental loss, damage or destruction, including as appropriate:
the pseudonymisation and encryption of Customer Personal Data;
the ability to ensure the ongoing confidentiality, integrity, availability and resilience of its processing systems and services;
the ability to restore the availability of and access to Customer Personal Data in a timely manner in the event of a physical or technical incident; and
a process for regularly assessing and evaluating the effectiveness of technical and organisational measures for ensuring the security of the processing;
ensure that:
access to Customer Personnel Data is restricted only to those Supplier Personnel who need access to perform the Services; and
all Supplier Personnel who have access to or process Customer Personal Data are obliged to keep the personal data confidential;

promptly assist the Customer[, at the Supplier's expense,] in responding to any request from a data subject and in ensuring compliance with the Customer's obligations under Applicable Data Protection Laws with respect to security, breach notifications, impact assessments and consultations with the Commissioner or other Regulators. In particular, the Supplier shall promptly notify the Customer if it receives any complaint, notice or communication (whether from a data subject, the Commissioner or any other Regulator or third party) which relates to processing of Customer Personal Data;
notify the Customer without undue delay (and no later than [TIMESCALE]) after becoming aware of a personal data breach;

at the written direction of the Customer, delete or return to the Customer all Customer Personal Data when it is no longer needed to perform the Services and in any event on termination or expiry of this agreement, unless the Supplier is required by Applicable Law to continue to process that Customer Personal Data. The Supplier shall procure that any third party to which the Supplier has disclosed the Customer Personal Data does the same and shall certify to the Customer in writing that it has complied with this clause 13.7(f). [If the Supplier is required by Applicable Law to continue to process any Customer Personal Data, the Supplier shall promptly notify the Customer of what that Applicable Law is and shall only be permitted to process that Customer Personal Data for that specific purpose. All requirements set out in this clause 13 shall continue to apply to any Customer Personal Data for as long as that Customer Personal Data is processed by the Supplier.] For the purposes of this clause 13.7(f) the obligation to "delete" data includes the obligation to delete data from back-up systems as well as live systems; and

maintain complete and accurate records and information to demonstrate its compliance with Applicable Data Protection Laws and this clause 13 and make them available to the Customer on request. The Supplier shall allow for and submit its premises and operations to audits, including inspections, by the Customer or the Customer's designated auditor to demonstrate its compliance with Applicable Data Protection Laws and this clause 13. [The requirements of clause 9 apply to any audits under this clause 13.]
The Supplier shall not engage a third party to process any Customer Personal Data without the prior written consent of the Customer [(not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)]. The Supplier shall:
ensure that the terms on which it appoints any third party processor comply with Applicable Data Protection Laws and are consistent with the obligations imposed on the Supplier in this clause 13; and
remain responsible for the acts and omissions of that third party as if they were the acts and omissions of the Supplier.

The Supplier shall not carry out, via itself or via any other processor, any processing of Customer Personal Data, or transfer any Customer Personal Data, outside of the UK [or EEA], including processing Customer Personal Data on equipment situated outside of the UK [or EEA] unless the prior written consent of the Customer has been obtained and the Supplier:
ensures that the processing is compliant with Applicable Data Protection Laws, including by ensuring an adequate level of protection for the Customer Personal Data; and
complies with any reasonable instructions notified to it by the Customer with respect to the processing of the Customer Personal Data.
The Supplier shall not do anything which may cause the Customer to be in breach of Applicable Data Protection Laws or damage its reputation with data subjects.
A confidentiality clause aims to ensure that:
Confidential information disclosed by one party to the other is kept secret.
The party receiving the confidential information only uses the information in connection with the purpose of the agreement and not for any other purpose.

These confidentiality provisions are mutual. A customer with sufficient leverage may seek to make this a unilateral confidentiality obligation for the supplier but both parties are likely to have information they want to protect. Depending on the nature of the services:

The supplier may be using proprietary techniques or methodologies to perform the services. Details of these may need to be shared with the customer. The supplier's pricing may also be bespoke to the customer and therefore confidential.

The customer typically discloses proprietary business information that the supplier needs to be able to perform the services. If supplier personnel are on-site at the customer's offices, they may observe a variety of confidential information.
For further information on confidentiality and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Confidentiality and its drafting notes.
For further protection for the customer's confidential information, the customer could consider restricting the supplier from working for the customer's competitors. See optional clause 15.
Each party shall keep the other party's Confidential Information secret and confidential and shall not:
use that Confidential Information except for the purpose of exercising or performing its rights and obligations under or in connection with this agreement (Permitted Purpose); or
disclose that Confidential Information in whole or in part to any person, except as permitted by clause 14.2 [or clause 14.3].
Each party may disclose the other party's Confidential Information:

to [those of] its [and its Affiliates'] employees, officers, representatives, independent contractors, subcontractors and advisers who need to know that information for the Permitted Purpose (Representatives). Each party shall ensure that its Representatives comply with confidentiality obligations which are substantially equivalent to those set out in this clause 14; and

as may be required by law, a court of competent jurisdiction or any governmental or regulatory authority, provided that, to the extent it is legally permitted to do so, it gives the other party as much notice of the disclosure as possible [and, where notice of disclosure is not prohibited, it takes into account the reasonable requests of the other party in relation to the content of the disclosure].

The Customer may disclose the Supplier's Confidential Information [(excluding Confidential Information concerning the Charges and [OTHER RESTRICTED INFORMATION])] to any actual or potential Replacement Supplier to the extent reasonably necessary to plan for an exit from this agreement or to facilitate the smooth transition of the Services to a new supplier, provided that the Customer ensures any recipient of Confidential Information under this clause 14.3 complies with confidentiality obligations which are substantially equivalent to those set out in this clause 14.

head.headtext: Sharing confidential information with replacement suppliers

para.paratext: The customer is likely to want the supplier to co-operate in transferring services to a new supplier when the agreement ends (see clause 20.2). This requirement is fairly common in services agreements and therefore something that the supplier may have to accept.

If the supplier objects to the clause, consider specifying the sensitive information, such as pricing information, that the customer should not be able to share with a new supplier who may be a competitor of the existing supplier.

The Supplier shall [not process the Customer's Confidential Information in any way using machine learning or artificial intelligence (AI) models OR only process the Customer's Confidential Information using machine learning or artificial intelligence (AI) models where those models will not be:
trained on the Customer's Confidential Information; and
lawfully available to or accessible for use by any person or entity except the Supplier or its Representatives.

With AI use becoming ever more prevalent in a commercial context, the customer should consider expressly addressing the supplier's potential use of AI and machine learning to perform the services, including how this interfaces with the need to protect the confidential information disclosed.
If including this optional clause 14.4, choose from the following two drafting options:

Option 1. Unless there is a transaction-specific reason to permit it, the customer should consider prohibiting the use of its confidential information by AI or machine learning models (whether private or public facing) in the supply of the services. This broad prohibition also prevents use of the disclosed confidential information to train those models. Particularly with a public facing AI model (for example, Chat GPT), this helps address the risk that the customer's confidential information may be used to train the model to respond to future queries by members of the public, and so lead to potential data leakage (unauthorised disclosure to third parties). The first drafting option at clause 14.4(a) reflects this approach.

Option 2. If the supplier intends to use AI to provide the services and the customer accepts that, the customer should consider imposing a condition on the supplier that any customer confidential information fed into the AI model will not be used to train it, and that the AI model is not accessible to or available for use by anyone that is not already allowed to access the confidential information under the agreement. Choose the second drafting option at clause 14.4(b), if taking this approach.
For further information on AI and confidentiality, see Practice note, Protecting confidential information: overview: Artificial intelligence (AI) and confidentiality.

The provisions of this clause 14 shall continue to apply [after termination or expiry of this agreement OR for a period of [five] years after termination or expiry of this agreement OR indefinitely after termination or expiry of this agreement in relation to [CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION TO BE PROTECTED INDEFINITELY] and for a period of [five] years after termination or expiry for all other Confidential Information].
In clause 14.5, there are three options for how long the confidentiality commitments should continue after the agreement ends:

The first option says that the confidentiality commitments continue indefinitely, although information may naturally lose the qualities of being confidential as time goes by. Where the customer is disclosing particularly sensitive confidential information, it may want to choose this option.
The second option puts a time limit on post-termination confidentiality commitments.

The third option is a mix of options one and two. The confidentiality commitments can continue indefinitely for some highly sensitive information and for a fixed period of time for other information. This is a compromise between the first two options.

The customer may want to include a non-compete clause that prevents the supplier from supplying the same or similar services to the customer's competitors. The customer may see this clause as being necessary to reduce the risk of its confidential information being disclosed to a competitor, resulting in a loss of competitive advantage. For example, if a marketing services supplier is working on the launch of a new product for one customer, with access to highly confidential information, that customer is unlikely to accept that supplier also working for its main competitor due to the risk of secret information leaking from the supplier to the competitor.

This kind of provision may be unenforceable or against public policy if its scope is held to be unreasonable. Unless the customer is providing substantial business to the supplier or the supplier is gaining access to particularly important confidential information belonging to the customer, the supplier is likely to object to its inclusion.

For more information on non-compete provisions in supply agreements and alternative drafting, see Standard clauses, Exclusive purchasing and supply clause: short form and Exclusive purchasing and supply clause: long form. The long-form clause includes drafting requiring the supplier to put in place ethical walls between teams where it is allowed to service competitors.

During the Term [and for [DURATION] months after termination or expiry of this agreement], the Supplier shall not supply[, and shall procure that none of its Affiliates supplies,] services which are the same as or substantially similar to the Services to any Competitor in the Territory without the Customer's prior written approval [(not to be unreasonably withheld, conditioned or delayed)]. Competitor means any business whose products or services are [directly] in competition with the Customer's [CUSTOMER'S PRODUCTS, SERVICES OR INDUSTRY OR THE RELEVANT PART THAT THE SUPPLIER WILL BE SUPPLYING] in the Territory[, including [COMPETITOR NAMES]]. Territory means [DESCRIBE].

Generally, the supplier should bear the risk that its services infringe third party rights. The supplier should ensure that no part of the services or deliverables has been copied or extracted from a third party source without permission. As such, it is common for the supplier to give a warranty that the IPRs in the services and deliverables do not infringe any third party's IPRs (see clause 16.4(a)) and to indemnify the customer for any losses if there is a third party infringement claim (see clause 16.5(a)).

The supplier is not liable to the extent that the infringement is caused by the customer's actions or materials (see clause 16.6). The customer can limit this carve-out so that it only applies where customer materials are used in accordance with the customer's instructions.
As this is a pro-customer agreement:
The supplier's indemnity is not subject to the limitations or exclusions of liability in clause 18.

There is a basic warranty that customer materials licensed to the supplier under clause 10.1 do not infringe third party IPRs but there is no corresponding IPR indemnity from the customer to the supplier against third party infringement claims.

Where the supplier is working with materials provided by the customer to a significant extent, the supplier may insist on the customer providing an indemnity against those materials infringing third party rights. For an indemnity from the customer that could be included in this agreement, see Standard document, Services agreement (pro-supplier): clause 11.9(b).

An indemnity for infringement of IPRs is sometimes accompanied by a right or an obligation for the indemnifying party to try to avoid the claim by procuring a licence to use the infringing item or modifying it so that it ceases to infringe. If the indemnifying party fails to do so, the indemnified party can terminate the agreement and receive a refund of charges in relation to the infringing items. For this drafting, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: long form: clause 34.3.

A supplier with sufficient negotiating leverage may refuse to give the warranty and representation in clause 16.4(a) and require the customer to rely on the intellectual property indemnity in clause 16.5(a) as its sole remedy for third-party infringement claims. Customers often want a warranty and representation, as well as an indemnity, so that they can:
Claim damages from the supplier where it creates infringing material but there is no third party claim.
Terminate the agreement for breach.
Potentially rescind the agreement for misrepresentation.
The indemnity in clause 16.5(c) is designed to protect the customer from third party claims that result from the failure of the supplier to comply with data protection law or clause 13.

This situation might arise where, for example, the supplier is processing personal data about the customer's customers on behalf of the customer and the supplier loses that data. The customer may then suffer claims by individuals that their rights under data protection law have been infringed and regulatory action. This indemnity is subject to a separate liability cap in clause 18.
A customer in a particularly strong bargaining position may try to make liability under this indemnity unlimited.

If the supplier fails to comply with applicable laws or, more narrowly, key regulatory obligations (for example, anti-bribery laws) and that results in action against the customer, the optional indemnity in clause 16.5(b) allows the customer to pass through the fines, penalties and any other resulting losses to the supplier.
Each party warrants and represents to the other party that:
it has full power and authority to enter into this agreement and fulfil its obligations under it;
this agreement is executed by its duly authorised representative;

there are no actions, suits or proceedings or regulatory investigations pending or, to that party's knowledge, threatened against or affecting that party before any court or administrative body or arbitration tribunal that might affect its ability to meet and carry out its obligations under this agreement; and
its obligations under this agreement constitute its legal, valid, and binding obligations.

The Supplier warrants and represents that all written statements and representations made by the Supplier as part of the procurement process are true and accurate except to the extent that the Supplier has otherwise disclosed to the Customer in writing before the date of this agreement.

A customer in a strong bargaining position may be able to commit the supplier to promises made as part of any pre-contract procurement process or at least force the supplier to disclose any areas where it has misrepresented its capabilities.
The supplier may argue that statements made during the procurement process were not drafted with the intention that they should be legally binding and are insufficiently specific.

The Customer warrants and represents that the Customer Materials do not infringe the Intellectual Property Rights or any other rights of any third party. The Customer shall not be liable under this clause 16.3 to the extent that the infringement arises from:
changes made to the Customer Materials without the Customer's prior written consent; or
the use of the Customer Materials for a purpose or in a manner not authorised by the Customer in writing.
The Supplier warrants, represents and undertakes that:
subject to clause 16.6, the supply, receipt, and use of the Services and Deliverables shall not infringe the Intellectual Property Rights or any other rights of any third party;
it is not, and shall not become, subject to any contractual obligation which is likely to have a material adverse effect on its ability to perform its obligations under this agreement; and
it shall not do anything that could reasonably be considered to bring the Customer into disrepute or damage its reputation.
These statements are drafted as undertakings, as well as warranties and representations, as they also relate to future duties.

The customer should consider whether the additional warranties, representations and undertakings in clause 16.4 are appropriate for the specific services being provided. For example, if the services include providing software, whether assigned or licensed to the customer, the customer may consider including warranties specifying that the software will not include any viruses or other harmful code or disabling mechanisms or any open-source software. For customer-friendly warranties when licensing software, see Standard document, Software licence agreement (pro-customer): clause 8.
From the supplier's perspective, it should consider:
Expanding the carve-outs from clause 16.4(a). See clause 16.6.

Deleting or diluting clause 16.4(c). For example, an advertising agency could be asked to run a campaign for the customer that is deliberately provocative. It should not be in breach of this clause where it does so on the customer's instructions.
The Supplier shall indemnify [the Customer OR each Indemnified Person] against all Losses incurred by the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] as a result of:
any claim that the supply, receipt or use of any of the Services or Deliverables infringes the Intellectual Property Rights or any other rights of any third party; [and]

This clause 16.5(a) is a fairly typical IPR indemnity. The customer should consider whether it is necessary to extend the indemnity to other claims that may be triggered by the deliverables, such as claims that the deliverables are defamatory or discriminatory.

For example, a customer may engage a supplier to undertake a recruitment exercise. The supplier may deploy an AI system that has been trained on datasets that have an inherent bias against one or more categories of candidate. The customer may then receive claims from candidates and be liable under section 109(2) of the Equality Act 2010.

any claim by any person, or any action (including any investigation) by a Regulator or governmental authority, arising out of or in connection with the Supplier's failure to comply with [Applicable Laws OR the Relevant Requirements] or breach of clause 12.5; and

any claim by any person, or any action or investigation by a Regulator, arising out of or in connection with the Supplier's failure to comply with Applicable Data Protection Laws or breach of clause 13.

[In this clause 16.5, Indemnified Persons mean the Customer and each of its Affiliates [and each of its and their directors, officers, employees, agents and licensees], and Indemnified Person means any of them.]
Clause 16.5 includes optional wording to extend the indemnity protection from the customer to its affiliates and other related parties.

The supplier may argue that this extended indemnity protection is unnecessary given the nature of the services and that the customer should be the sole beneficiary. Even if there is an argument for extended protection (for example, because customer affiliates are beneficiaries of the services), the supplier may still object to multiple parties being able to bring different claims against it under the indemnity over the same issue.
One solution is to allow the customer to recover losses for itself and on behalf of its related parties, such as affiliates, but with only the customer able to bring claims against the supplier.
The Supplier shall not be liable under the warranty in clause 16.4(a) or the indemnity in clause 16.5(a) to the extent that the actual or alleged infringement arises directly from:
any changes made to the Deliverables by the Customer [or any of its licensees] without the Supplier's prior written consent, which shall not be unreasonably conditioned, withheld or delayed; or

the [use of the] Customer Materials [in accordance with the Customer's instructions][, provided that the Supplier shall not be relieved of liability where it knew or suspected (or should have known or suspected) that the use of any Customer Materials may result in infringement but did not notify the Customer].

head.headtext: Exceptions to IPR warranties and indemnities

para.paratext: The supplier will want exceptions to its IPR warranties and indemnities so that they do not apply where the supplier is not the source of the infringement.

The supplier may want to expand the exceptions in clause 16.6 so that it is not liable, for example, where the infringement is caused by the customer's instructions or by the customer using the deliverables for a purpose or in a manner that is not authorised by the supplier.
For an expanded set of exceptions, see Standard clause, Indemnity: clause 1.3.

The drafting in brackets in clause 16.6(b) benefits the customer. It has the effect that the supplier is still liable under the indemnity if the infringement results from the supplier misusing the customer materials.

If a third party brings a claim against [the Customer OR any Indemnified Person], or notifies [the Customer OR any Indemnified Person] of its intention to do so, and that claim may reasonably be considered likely to give rise to a liability under an indemnity in this clause 16 (Claim), the Customer shall[, or shall procure that the Indemnified Person shall]:
as soon as reasonably practicable, give written notice of the Claim to the Supplier, specifying the nature of the Claim in reasonable detail;

subject to clause 16.8, allow the Supplier, at its own cost, to conduct all negotiations and proceedings in relation to the Claim and to settle or compromise the Claim, provided that the Supplier may not settle or compromise the Claim [without the prior written consent of the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] (consent not to be unreasonably withheld) OR unless it involves only the payment of money by the Supplier and includes a complete release of the [Customer OR Indemnified Person]];
provide the Supplier with reasonable information, assistance and co-operation in responding to and defending the Claim, subject to the Supplier's compliance with clause 16.9(c); and

not, subject to clause 16.8 and the Supplier's full compliance with clause 16.9, make any admission of liability, settlement or compromise relating to the Claim without the Supplier's prior written consent (not to be unreasonably conditioned, withheld or delayed)[, provided that the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] may settle the Claim (after giving prior written notice of the terms of settlement (to the extent legally possible) to the Supplier), but without obtaining the Supplier's consent, if [the full and final settlement of the Claim comprises only the payment of money and] the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] [reasonably] believes that failure to settle the Claim would be prejudicial to it in any material respect].

head.headtext: Conduct of claims: customer's duties (optional clause)

para.paratext: It is reasonable to expect that if the supplier is giving an indemnity to the customer in relation to third party claims, it will want to have some control over those claims. Otherwise, the risk for the supplier is that the customer may agree to a large settlement or run up disproportionate costs in defending the claims, and the supplier will have to pick up the bill. On the other hand, the customer may argue that the supplier should not have control over the conduct of third party claims on the grounds that the customer needs to keep control over claims against it for reputational reasons.

The customer may want to see evidence that the supplier can competently dispose of third party claims before allowing it to control the conduct of claims. If the customer is unconvinced that the supplier can handle third party claims, it will not want it to have any say in how they are dealt with and will not include clause 16.7.

Where the customer accepts that the supplier is best placed to handle third party claims (which will often be the case with third party IPR infringement claims), it may still want to retain as much control as possible over claims which could damage its brand. In this situation, the customer may insist on wording that:
Requires the supplier to obtain the customer's consent to settlement or at least obtain a complete release for the customer in any settlement (clause 16.7(b)).

Gives the customer the right to settle claims prejudicial to it (clause 16.7(d)). However, it may be that the supplier simply cannot agree to the optional wording in clause 16.7(d) because it could result in an excessively high indemnity bill for the supplier or bind the supplier to take certain action in respect of its IPR which the supplier is unwilling to take.
For more information on conduct of claims provisions generally, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Indemnity.

If the Supplier does not assume control over the defence of a Claim within [NUMBER] days of receipt of the notice under clause 16.7(a), the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] may defend the Claim in any way it deems appropriate at the Supplier's expense.
If the Supplier assumes control over the defence of a Claim, the Supplier shall:
defend the Claim diligently, using competent counsel and in such a way as not to bring the reputation of the Customer [or any of its Affiliates] into disrepute;
have regard to the interests and reputation of the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] in its conduct of the Claim;
reimburse the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] for any costs incurred under clause 16.7(c);

ensure that the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] is granted access to all relevant documents connected with the Claim and keep the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] informed, at regular intervals, regarding negotiations, litigation and other material matters concerning the Claim; and
allow the [Customer OR Indemnified Person] to join in the defence of the Claim with counsel of its choice at its own expense.

head.headtext: Conduct of claims: supplier's duties (optional clauses)

para.paratext: The provisions in clause 16.9 assume that the customer has agreed to allow the supplier some control over the conduct of third party claims against the customer. They are drafted to be customer-friendly, for example, by requiring the supplier to handle claims in a way that minimises reputational damage to the customer.
The failure of the Customer to comply with the indemnification procedures in clause 16.7 does not relieve the Supplier of any obligation to indemnify the [Customer OR Indemnified Person].

head.headtext: Conduct of claims: consequences of non-compliance (optional clause)

para.paratext: Failure by the customer to comply with conduct of claims requirements does not relieve the supplier of its duty to indemnify the customer. This favours the customer, although the supplier may still have a damages claim against the customer for breach of clause 16.7.

If the supplier objects to this clause 16.10, the customer could include a compromise position where liability under the indemnity is reduced to the extent that any losses are caused by its non-compliance with the conduct of claims requirements (see Standard clause, Indemnity: clause 1.8).

If a payment due from the Supplier under clause 16.5 is subject to tax (whether by way of direct assessment or withholding at its source), the amount of the payment shall be increased to ensure that the net receipt, after tax, to the beneficiary of the indemnity is the same as it would have been were the payment not subject to tax.

Insurance is generally optional in services agreements. If the customer is concerned about the supplier's ability to meet any liabilities it may incur under this agreement, insurance is one way to address that concern.

This insurance obligation is suitable for low-risk or low-value contracts. For higher risk or higher value contracts, more detailed provisions may be necessary, such as clauses that require the supplier to:
Put in place insurance which is specific to the services in question.
Take out other types of insurance, such as employer's liability insurance or product liability insurance.
Ensure the customer's interest is noted on the policies.
Provide evidence that policies have been renewed.
For an example of a more detailed insurance clause, see Standard clause, Insurance and its drafting notes.

The level of insurance cover should be considered when negotiating the limitation of the supplier's liability at clause 18. See Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Consider what insurance is available.

During the Term [and for a period of [PERIOD] after the expiry or termination of this agreement,] the Supplier shall maintain in force adequate insurance, with reputable insurance companies, to cover its potential liabilities under or in connection with this agreement[, including:
public liability insurance with a limit of no less than Â£[AMOUNT] per claim; and
professional indemnity insurance with a limit of no less than Â£[AMOUNT] for claims arising from a single event or series of related events in a single calendar year].

The Supplier shall produce to the Customer on request a certificate of insurance from each of its insurers evidencing the insurance required by this agreement [and a receipt for the current year's premium in respect of each insurance].
Limitation of liability is a key issue in a services contract and is likely to be the subject of heavy negotiation between the parties. Tailor this clause 18 for your particular transaction.

head.headtext: Reasons for a limitation clause in a pro-customer contract

para.paratext: Sometimes pro-customer agreements do not contain any limitation or exclusion of liability for breach of contract for either party. This approach generally favours the customer, as it is the supplier, as the performing party, who usually takes on the greater risk under the contract. While the customer's own liability under the contract is unlimited, the customer may be prepared to accept this risk if its principal obligation is only to pay the charges.

In practice, it is unusual for a supplier to accept this approach. The supplier may argue that to remain in business and continue serving the customer it needs to cap its liability in a sensible way. Without limits on its liability, the risk of potential liability may outweigh the value of the contract for the supplier.
A customer may therefore prefer to include a limitation clause which benefits both parties but is more favourable to the customer.
This clause sets out a typical structure for a limitation of liability clause which is commonly found in services agreements. It is divided into the following sections:

Unlimited liabilities. Neither party limits those liabilities which cannot be limited as a matter of law. There is also the option to leave other potential liabilities unlimited, such as those arising under indemnities.

Excluded liabilities. Clause 18.6 provides wording to exclude certain categories of loss, such as indirect and consequential loss. There is also wording to clarify that certain losses are not subject to these exclusions.

Capped liabilities. Each party limits all other liabilities which might arise to a capped amount. The drafting clarifies whether or not certain payments under the agreement count towards and reduce the available cap.
For more information on limitations of liability and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability.
The following definitions apply in this clause 18:
default: any act or omission resulting in one party incurring liability to the other; and
liability: every kind of liability arising under or in connection with this agreement including liability in contract, tort (including negligence), or otherwise.

head.headtext: Scope of limitations in this clause

para.paratext: This clause 18.1 is designed to ensure that the caps and exclusions capture not just liability for breach of contract but also other liabilities "in connection with" the contract. These could include liability for breach of confidence, misrepresentation, undue influence, or torts such as negligence, conversion and breach of statutory duty.
Some liabilities need clear words to limit them, namely:

Negligence: expressly limited in clause 18.1. For more information, see Practice note, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: Negligence: express reference safest for exclusion.

Deliberate breach: not included in clause 18.1 because this is a pro-customer agreement but it could be expressly limited by inserting "deliberate default" after "(including negligence)" in clause 18.1. If this is done, delete the reference in clause 18.2(a)(i) to liability for deliberate default being unlimited.
For more information about this clause, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: Drafting note: Scope of this clause (long form).
Nothing in this agreement limits or excludes:
either party's liability for:
deliberate [or wilful] default;

head.headtext: No limitations in respect of deliberate default

para.paratext: Where a party's liability is limited, there is a risk that it will decide that it is cheaper to walk away from a contract, or simply not perform part of it, and incur the limited liability rather than the costs of complying with the contract. This clause 18.2(a)(i) is intended to deter a party from doing this by disapplying the limits and exclusions where liability arises from deliberate default.

While the clause could help to stop the supplier from abandoning the contract, it may also help the supplier by making the customer's liability unlimited if the customer deliberately refuses to pay invoices. If the supplier insists on an express carve-out of payment obligations from limitations of liability, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: clause 1.2(f).
Customers often want to make wilful (that is, reckless) defaults unlimited, as well as intentional acts. There is optional drafting for this.
For the meaning of deliberate default and wilful misconduct, see Practice note, Limiting liability: interpretation: "Deliberate default" and "Wilful misconduct" and "wilful default".
death or personal injury caused by negligence to the extent preserved by section 2(1) of the Unfair Contract Terms Act 1977;
fraud or fraudulent misrepresentation;
breach of the terms implied by section 2 of the Supply of Goods and Services Act 1982;
any liability that cannot legally be limited or excluded;

Statute prohibits the limitation or exclusion of the claims listed in clause 18.2(a)(ii) and clause 18.2(a)(iv) (see Practice note, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: Liabilities parties cannot limit).

Case law establishes that, as a matter of public policy, a party cannot exclude liability for its own fraudulent misrepresentation inducing contract formation. It is not entirely clear whether a party can exclude its liability for other types of fraud (particularly by a party's agents). However, in practice, parties generally want losses resulting from fraud to be uncapped and clause 18.2(a)(iii) aims to achieve this.
See Practice note, Limiting liability: statutory and common law controls on limitation clauses: Public policy against fraud (dishonesty).
the Supplier's liability under clause 16.5(a) [or Drafting note, IPR indemnity] of this agreement; or
[the Supplier's OR either party's] liability under the indemnities in Schedule 6.
The purpose of clause 18.2(b) and clause 18.2(c) is to ensure that certain liabilities arising under the terms of the agreement are not subject to the limitations of liability.

As this is a pro-customer agreement, the approach here is that the supplier's liability under the IPR indemnity in clause 16.5(a) and the regulatory indemnity in Drafting note, IPR indemnity (if included) are uncapped.

The customer's rationale is that these are key areas where the customer may incur significant liability, or suffer serious reputational damage, due to the supplier's misconduct and that the customer has no control over the relevant risks.

If the supplier objects to unlimited liability, an alternative option is to have a separate cap (or caps) for these risks, set at a level significantly above the general liability cap. This is the approach taken with the data protection indemnity in clause 16.5(c) (see the separate cap for this in clause 18.3(b)).
TUPE indemnities are usually excluded from limitations of liability.
For more on the interaction between indemnity clauses and liability caps, see Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Check interaction with indemnities.
Subject to clause 18.2, the Supplier's total liability:

for damage to customer property shall not exceed Â£[AMOUNT] for any one default or series of connected defaults. Customer property means premises, equipment or other property (but excluding data) owned, controlled or occupied by the Customer [or any of its Affiliates] and which are made available for use by the Supplier or any of its suppliers;
[under OR for each breach of] clause 13 and [under OR for each claim [by the Customer OR any Indemnified Person] under] the indemnity in clause 16.5(c) shall not exceed Â£[AMOUNT]; and

for all other loss or damage [arising from defaults occurring within any Contract Year] shall not exceed [Â£[AMOUNT] OR the greater of Â£[AMOUNT] and [150]% of the Charges paid or payable under this agreement] [in that Contract Year].
There are various ways to structure a liability cap (see Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: Ways to structure a cap).
The approach in this clause 18.3 is for the supplier to have separate liability caps for:

Property damage. This would be relevant if there is a risk that the supplier's staff may cause damage to the customer's property (or vice versa). The property damage cap is drafted on a per event basis. Additional wording clarifies what is meant by property. As a pro-customer agreement, this is drafted broadly to include items such as equipment and other assets, as well as premises. If the risk of property damage is minimal, the customer may choose not to include a separate cap for property damage.

Liability for data processing breaches. Given the potentially high fines for data processing breaches under the UK GDPR, it is more likely that suppliers will seek some sort of financial cap on their liability to the customer for data processing breaches which is separate from, and in addition to, the contract's overall liability cap. Having a separate cap for this avoids the risk of data protection liabilities exhausting all or most of a general cap, so that there is none left for other liabilities that are subsequently incurred. The drafting provides options for an overall cap or a cap per breach or indemnity claim.
All other losses that do not come under any of the first two headings. This general cap is drafted as either:

a fixed amount. This may be most appropriate where the value of the contract is clear from the start. The fixed amount could simply be a multiple of the total sums payable over the full term of the agreement; or

the greater of a fixed amount and a percentage of charges. This may be most appropriate where the parties are uncertain of what the charges will be and also want to ensure that a minimum amount is recoverable in the early days of the contract, where few services have been supplied and so the charges are low.
The general cap provides two options:
A single cap for the duration of the contract. This option is likely to be best where the contract is short term.

An annual cap. This option is often used where services are provided over several years. For the customer, an annual cap avoids a situation in which the supplier, having paid out compensation once, has little or no liability for the remainder of the contract term. There are also benefits for the supplier. An annual cap prevents a situation in which the supplier's liability, being linked to the charges, increases year on year in a long term contract.

To add an additional liability cap for other specific issues (for example, liability under the indemnity in Drafting note, IPR indemnity), copy the wording in clause 18.2(b) for the data protection cap but replace references to data protection with the issues that you do want to cap.
For other drafting options, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: clause 1.3.
The supplier may argue that capping its liability at 150% of the charges is excessive. It may claim that its liability should be capped at 100% of the charges like the customer's.

From the customer's perspective, the supplier carries the bulk of the responsibilities under the agreement and has significant scope to cause the customer loss. The customer wants to have headroom to recover losses in excess of the charges.

Subject to clause 18.2, the Customer's total liability [arising from defaults occurring within any Contract Year] shall not exceed [Â£[AMOUNT] OR the greater of Â£[AMOUNT] and [100]% of the Charges paid or payable under this agreement] [in that Contract Year].

This clause 18.4 places a separate (generally lower) cap on the customer's liability. While the customer's main liability will be to pay, it will also be required to co-operate in the provision of the services. Failure to do this could result in claims for lost time or increased costs. The customer could also incur liability for wrongful termination if it seeks to terminate the agreement without justification.
The argument for setting the customer's liability lower is that the customer has fewer obligations. However, from a negotiating point of view, it is generally easier to agree a mutual cap.

As this agreement is customer-friendly, it does not include separate caps for property damage or data protection breaches. The customer would argue that these separate caps are not needed because it does not have the same potential to cause the supplier loss in these areas as the supplier has to cause the customer loss.

However, if the customer's breaches of data protection law could potentially cause the supplier significant loss (for example, where the supplier is reliant on the customer to obtain permissions to process personal data), the supplier may insist on a separate data protection cap.
For alternative drafting options, including a data protection cap, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: clause 1.4.
The caps on each party's liabilities shall not be reduced by:
payment of an uncapped liability; [or]
amounts paid under clause 4.2(c) or [OTHER CLAUSE]; or
amounts awarded by a court or arbitrator, using their procedural or statutory powers in respect of costs of proceedings or interest for late payment.
This clause 18.5 clarifies that certain sums paid do not count towards using up the supplier's liability cap(s). These are:
Payments of uncapped liabilities. See the uncapped liabilities in clause 18.2.

Payments due under specific clauses. For example, if the supplier has to pay liquidated damages for delay under clause 4.2(c), the customer will not want those payments to count towards using up the liability cap. If the supplier is required to make other payments under the terms of the agreement, such as service credits, then this clause could be adapted to clarify that those payments do not use up the liability cap(s).
Payments awarded at the discretion of the courts or an arbitrator. For example, payments incurred as a result of proceedings, such as costs and interest.
For more information, see Practice note, Limiting liability: drafting and negotiating: What counts towards the cap?.
Subject to clause 18.2 and clause 18.7, neither party shall have any liability for [loss of profits or] indirect or consequential loss.

This clause 18.6 sets out types of losses that are excluded. As the bulk of the obligations under the agreement sit with the supplier, the supplier is more likely to incur liability and want a long list of excluded losses.

The customer is more likely to prefer a short or no list of excluded losses. The drafting above is fairly customer-friendly while attempting to give some comfort to the supplier (namely via the exclusion of loss of profits).

An exclusion of indirect loss alone is unlikely to provide much protection for the supplier. It does not exclude losses that are the natural result of a breach of contract, including most financial losses. For more information, see Practice note, Limiting liability: interpretation: "Indirect and consequential loss".
For an extended list of losses to exclude, including loss of business, loss of goodwill and loss of data, see Standard clause, Limitation of liability: clause 1.6.
Clause 18.6 does not exclude any liability the Supplier may have for:
sums paid by the Customer to the Supplier pursuant to this agreement in respect of any Services not provided in accordance with this agreement;
wasted expenditure;

[reasonable] costs and expenses [necessarily] incurred by the Customer in remedying the Supplier's default[. These include consultancy costs, additional costs of management time and other personnel costs, and costs of equipment and materials];
[reasonable] costs incurred by the Customer in procuring and implementing replacements for, or alternatives to, Services not provided in accordance with this agreement;

losses incurred by the Customer arising out of or in connection with any third party claim against the Customer which has been caused by the Supplier's default. For these purposes, third party claims include demands, fines, penalties, actions, regulatory investigations or proceedings;
the loss of anticipated savings [in respect of [INDICATE SOURCE OF SAVINGS]]; and
[OTHER SPECIFIC LOSSES].

It may be in the customer's interests to list types of loss that are recoverable, despite the exclusion of certain categories of loss in clause 18.6. The intention is to reduce uncertainty about what the customer can recover.
The customer may consider expanding this list, for example, by adding the costs of restoring damaged or lost data and advertising costs incurred to limit damage to reputation.

The supplier may argue that it is for a court to decide which losses are recoverable and whether a loss is direct or indirect. Where the supplier objects to the inclusion of this clause 18.7, the customer could consider narrowing down the list of losses that are not excluded or qualifying those losses by reference to their reasonableness. In clause 18.7(f), the supplier may insist on the source of the anticipated savings being expressly referred to.

The wording from this clause 19 is largely taken from Standard clause, Termination. For more information on the termination provisions in this agreement and alternative, short-form drafting, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Termination.
The clause provides three sets of termination rights:

Clause 19.1 is a mutual termination clause enabling either party to terminate for material breach or insolvency-related events. However, a supplier's right to terminate for a customer's insolvency is severely restricted due to the effects of the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Act 2020 (CIGA 2020), as discussed in Drafting note, Termination for customer's insolvency: effects of CIGA 2020.

Clause 19.3 is a one-way termination clause giving the customer additional rights to terminate the contract if the supplier experiences a change of control or, optionally, breaches particularly critical clauses for the customer. Additional triggers permitting the customer to terminate may be added to the list.
Clause 19.4 allows the customer to terminate for convenience by giving a minimum notice period.

The supplier may ask for compensation where the customer terminates the contract early for convenience. The commercial justification for termination compensation is that the supplier may have invested a significant sum to set up the service provision for the customer, and a customer's exit before the expiry of an initial minimum term might prevent the supplier recouping those costs via the charges or fees. Determining the amount of compensation is a subject for negotiation. For further information, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: long form: Drafting note: Compensation for early termination (or termination for convenience). For termination payment drafting, see Standard clause, Consequences of termination or expiry: clause 1.2.

head.headtext: Termination for customer's insolvency: effects of CIGA 2020

para.paratext: With effect from 26 June 2020, CIGA 2020 introduced section 233B to the Insolvency Act 1986 (IA 1986). Broadly, this section makes it difficult for a supplier to terminate many contracts for the supply of goods or (non-financial) services once a customer has entered a formal corporate insolvency procedure. At this point:
Termination rights arising before the start of the insolvency period cannot be exercised (section 233B(4)).
A termination provision triggered by entry into the insolvency process has no effect (section 233B(3)).
To terminate the contract unilaterally, a supplier needs one of the following:
A new termination right, arising after the start of the insolvency process and not triggered by the process.
Consent from the officer appointed to run the company or the insolvency process, such as an administrator.
Court permission, granted due to the financial hardship caused to the supplier.

For a detailed discussion about the effects of CIGA 2020 on termination of contracts, see Practice note, Restrictions on terminating supply contracts in insolvency proceedings: Section 233B: no termination of supplies of goods and services generally.

A supplier affected by the restrictions on terminating for the customer's insolvency may want to include a clause enabling it to terminate at an early stage in the customer's financial problems (that is, before the customer enters insolvency). A sample of this is included in optional clause 19.1(m) but the customer could choose to omit it from the initial draft provided to the supplier. For more information about this subclause and other pre-insolvency termination triggers, see Standard clause, Termination: Drafting note: Financial difficulties (optional clause).

The supplier may want to include a specific termination right for late payment. The customer can point out that the supplier has a right to terminate for material breach and possibly persistant breach if clause 19.1(b) is included. Even so, the supplier may insist on a less ambiguous right to terminate for late payment. If the customer agrees to a right to terminate for late payment, it may want to:
Include an opportunity for the customer to fix the late payments before the termination right applies.
State that the right only applies if invoices over a certain amount are overdue.
Make the right mutual. This way, if the supplier owes money to the customer (for example, delay payments under clause 4.2(c)), the customer can terminate if the supplier is late paying.
For a clause allowing termination for late payment, see Standard clause, Termination: clause 1.1(a).
Without affecting any other right or remedy available to it, either party may terminate this agreement with immediate effect by notifying the other party if:
the other party commits a material breach of any term of this agreement that:
is not capable of remedy, or
if capable of remedy, is not remedied within a period of [NUMBER] days by the other party after being notified to do so;

the other party repeatedly breaches any of the terms of this agreement in such a manner as to reasonably justify the opinion that its conduct is inconsistent with it having the intention or ability to give effect to the terms of this agreement;

the other party suspends, or threatens to suspend, payment of its debts or is unable to pay its debts as they fall due or admits inability to pay its debts or is deemed unable to pay its debts within the meaning of section 123 of the Insolvency Act 1986 as if the words "it is proved to the satisfaction of the court" did not appear in sections 123(1)(e) or 123(2) of the Insolvency Act 1986;

the other party commences negotiations with all or any class of its creditors with a view to rescheduling any of its debts, or makes a proposal for or enters into any compromise or arrangement with any of its creditors [other than for the sole purpose of a scheme for a solvent amalgamation of that other party with one or more other companies or the solvent reconstruction of that other party];
the other party applies to court for, or obtains, a moratorium under Part A1 of the Insolvency Act 1986;

a petition is filed, a notice is given, a resolution is passed, or an order is made, for or in connection with the winding up of the other party [other than for the sole purpose of a scheme for a solvent amalgamation of that other party with one or more other companies or the solvent reconstruction of that other party];

an application is made to court, or an order is made, for the appointment of an administrator, or a notice of intention to appoint an administrator is given or an administrator is appointed, over the other party;
the holder of a qualifying floating charge over the assets of that other party has become entitled to appoint or has appointed an administrative receiver;
a person becomes entitled to appoint a receiver over all or any of the assets of the other party or a receiver is appointed over all or any of the assets of the other party;

a creditor or encumbrancer of the other party attaches or takes possession of, or a distress, execution, sequestration or other such process is levied or enforced on or sued against, the whole or any part of the other party's assets and that attachment or process is not discharged within [14] days;

any event occurs, or proceeding is taken, with respect to the other party in any jurisdiction to which it is subject that has an effect equivalent or similar to any of the events mentioned in clause 19.1(c) to clause 19.1(j) (inclusive); [or]
the other party suspends or ceases, or threatens to suspend or cease, carrying on all or a substantial part of its business[; or]
the other party's financial position deteriorates so far as to reasonably justify the opinion that its ability to give effect to the terms of this agreement is in jeopardy.
For the purposes of clause 19.1(a), material breach includes:
a breach of any of the obligations set out in clause 12, clause 13 or [CLAUSE NUMBER]; and
a breach that has a serious effect on the benefit the terminating party would otherwise derive from this agreement.
This optional definition of "material breach" seeks to add certainty by:
Identifying clauses whose breach is automatically material.
Stating what is material, in terms that focus on the effect on the terminating party (and not, for example, on the defaulting party's intention).

Where one party is in material breach, it has the chance to remedy the breach where the breach is remediable. The customer may feel that it should be able to terminate immediately (with no chance to remedy) if the supplier breaches some or all of the clauses mentioned in clause 19.2(a). If so, the customer should instead list those clauses in clause 19.3(c).
Without affecting any other right or remedy available to it, the Customer may terminate this agreement with immediate effect by notifying the Supplier if:
the Supplier fails to meet any [Milestone Date OR any Milestone Dates on [NUMBER] or more occasions];

head.headtext: Termination for missed milestone dates (optional clause)

para.paratext: Use the first option in clause 19.3(a) if time is of the essence for all milestone dates. Use the second option if time is not of the essence but the customer can terminate if the supplier is late performing on multiple occasions.
the Customer finally refuses to approve any Work Item under clause 4.6(c)) [on [NUMBER] or more occasions [in any [NUMBER] month period];

If the customer should have the right to terminate the whole agreement if the supplier fails to cure defective services after one attempt, remove the wording in brackets. In some circumstances, this may be appropriate but in others, this may be an excessive remedy for what may be a relatively small issue in the context of the whole agreement.
The wording in brackets allows the customer to terminate only if there are repeated failures to provide compliant services.
the Supplier commits a breach of [CLAUSE NUMBER]; or
Add any provisions to this clause 19.3(c) that entitle the customer to terminate immediately with no cure period.
there is a change of control of the Supplier [provided that:

the Customer has a bona fide concern that the Supplier will not be able to continue to provide the Services and perform its other obligations under this agreement in accordance with its terms after the change of control; and

the Customer gives notice to terminate within [three] months of the later of the date on which the change of control takes place and the date on which the Customer becomes aware of the change of control having taken place].

A customer termination right for change of control is fairly common in services agreements. Some suppliers may see it as disproportionate given that many changes of ownership have no impact on the stability of the supplier or the quality of its services.

If the supplier objects to this provision, the customer could use the optional wording to soften it. Through this optional drafting, the customer must have reasonable grounds to object to the change of control and must exercise its termination rights within a specific period.

The Customer may terminate this agreement for convenience[, in whole or in part,] by giving not less than [NUMBER] months' notice to the Supplier [provided that the Customer may not give notice to terminate under this clause 19.4 during the initial [NUMBER] months of the Term].

If the customer wants the right to terminate for convenience, the supplier may ask for compensation (see Drafting note, Termination). The customer could use the optional drafting in this clause 19.4 as a compromise so that notice of termination cannot be given during an initial period. This would allow the supplier time to recover set-up costs through the charges and hone its service provision before the customer is able to end the relationship without cause.
The supplier may try to include its own right to terminate for convenience, arguing that:
It should not be locked in to a relationship if it is not working.
If the customer has a right to terminate for convenience, it is only fair that it should have one too.

The customer would argue that the supplier is not locked into the contract indefinitely because of the contract term and can terminate for material breach or insolvency-related events if there are serious issues.

If the supplier insists on a right to terminate for convenience, the customer should make sure that the amount of notice that the supplier has to give is sufficient to enable the customer to source an alternative supplier.
Either party may terminate this agreement where it has the right to do so under [clause 12.2 or] clause 21.7.
Clause 20.1 deals with the supplier's obligations on termination or expiry of the agreement in relation to delivery up of the customer's equipment, materials and deliverables.
Clause 20.2 requires the supplier to help the customer transition the services to the customer or a new supplier when the agreement is coming to an end.

Clause 20.5 is a survival clause that deals with the effect of termination or expiry on the provisions of the agreement. It identifies the rights and obligations that continue after the termination of the agreement. The parties should ensure the clause includes the specific provisions applicable to their circumstances. For example, confidentiality and indemnification clauses are commonly included in the survival clause.
For more information on survival clauses, see Standard clause, Survival.
On termination or expiry of this agreement, the Supplier shall immediately (or on any alternative timeframe specified by the Customer for the purposes of clause 20.2):
deliver to the Customer all Deliverables, whether or not then complete;
return to the Customer all of the Customer Equipment and other customer property in the possession or control of the Supplier or any Supplier Personnel;
cease using (and return or destroy if required by the Customer) all Customer Materials and Customer Confidential Information in the possession or control of the Supplier or any Supplier Personnel;
comply with the requirements of clause 13.7(f) in relation to Customer Personal Data; and
remove any Supplier Equipment from the Customer's premises.

During the Termination Assistance Period, the Supplier shall provide all information and assistance reasonably required by the Customer to facilitate the smooth transition of the Services to the Customer or any Replacement Supplier appointed by it[, including by:
providing access to materials, data and personnel used in the performance of the Services;
providing reasonable assistance in support of any market testing or proposed procurement that the Customer may wish to carry out in relation to Replacement Services; and
co-operating with the Customer and any Replacement Supplier to enable an orderly handover of the Services].

Clause 20.2 places a general obligation on the supplier to help the customer with any exit assistance as is reasonably required by the customer. The aim is to minimise disruption to the services and preserve the continuity of the customer's business operations.

Some customers take the view that providing reasonable exit assistance is an integral part of the supplier's scope of work and remunerated by the margin earned by the supplier during the life of the contract. If the supplier insists on payment for termination assistance and the customer agrees to this, the customer could use the optional wording in clause 20.3 and clause 20.4 so that:
There is a cap on the costs that the supplier can claim for providing exit assistance.
The supplier is not paid for exit assistance if the customer terminates for cause.
The customer should also consider whether to include:
A schedule setting out the specific exit assistance that the customer requires.
A requirement for the supplier to develop an exit plan explaining how it will transition services back to the customer or a new supplier when the agreement expires or terminates.
For an example exit plan, see Standard clause, Exit management and Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: Shorter form: Schedule 14.
For a discussion of exit management generally, see Practice note, Main issues in outsourcing contracts: Exit management.
Subject to clause 20.4, the Customer shall reimburse the Supplier's reasonable, additional costs of carrying out its obligations under clause 20.2 provided that:
the Supplier shall not charge the Customer for supplying reports or information already within its possession or control;
[any costs are incurred at the rates set out in Schedule 2];
any costs [over Â£[AMOUNT]] are approved in advance in writing by the Customer before being incurred by the Supplier; and
the Supplier provides the Customer on request with any information needed to verify the costs to the Customer's reasonable satisfaction.

If the Customer terminates this agreement under clause 19.1[, clause 19.3(a), Drafting note, Termination for missed milestone dates (optional clause) or clause 19.3(c)], the Supplier shall bear its own costs in carrying out its obligations under clause 20.2.

Any provision of this agreement that expressly or by implication is intended to come into or continue in force on or after termination or expiry of this agreement shall remain in full force and effect, including clause 5.5, [clause 9,] clause 10, clause 13.7(f), clause 13.7(g), clause 14, [clause 15,] clause 16.5 to clause 16.11, [clause 17], clause 18, clause 20 and clause 34.

Termination or expiry of this agreement shall not affect any rights, remedies, obligations or liabilities of the parties that have accrued up to the date of termination or expiry, including the right to claim damages in respect of any breach of this agreement which existed at or before the date of termination or expiry.

This clause 21 is a standard force majeure clause which relieves both parties from their contractual obligations if a force majeure event occurs. It also sets out the actions that need to be taken to minimise the impact of the force majeure event and explains when the party not affected by force majeure can terminate.

The clause is drafted to favour the customer, as the party with fewer obligations and therefore less likely to invoke force majeure, while acknowledging that most suppliers expect some protection from the effects of force majeure.
For information on force majeure clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Force majeure.

head.headtext: Business continuity plan and force majeure clauses

para.paratext: This agreement does not include obligations on the supplier to produce a business continuity plan specifically for the customer. Those obligations are not necessary in all services agreements.

However, it is reasonable for the customer to expect the supplier to have general plans to minimise disruption within its operations due to force majeure events. In clause 21.4(b), the supplier can only benefit from force majeure protection if it took reasonable steps to prevent or minimise the impact of force majeure, including by implementing business continuity plans.
For obligations on a supplier to produce a business continuity plan specific to the customer in an outsourcing, see Standard document, Outsourcing agreement: long form: clause 42.
Force Majeure Event means [any circumstance not within a party's reasonable control including]:
The customer is likely to want to make this list exhaustive, so that only events falling within the categories listed are treated as force majeure events. If so, omit the words in square brackets.
acts of God, flood, drought, earthquake or other natural disaster;
epidemic or pandemic;
terrorist attack, civil war, civil commotion or riots, war, threat of or preparation for war, armed conflict, imposition of sanctions, embargo, or breaking off of diplomatic relations;
nuclear, chemical or biological contamination, or sonic boom;
any law or action taken by a government or public authority, including imposing an export or import restriction, quota, or prohibition;
collapse of buildings, fire, explosion or accident; [and]
any labour or trade dispute, strikes, industrial action or lockouts (other than by the staff of the party seeking to rely on this clause or those of its subcontractors [or Affiliates]); [and]
interruption or failure of utility service.

Subject to clause 21.4, a party (Affected Party) shall not be liable for any failure or delay in performing any of its obligations under this agreement for so long as, and to the extent that, its performance is [directly] prevented, hindered or delayed by a Force Majeure Event.

Consider whether to include "directly", which may make it harder to invoke the clause. For example, if there was some intervening cause between the force majeure event and the adverse impact, then the affected party would not be able to rely on it.
However, even if "directly" is omitted it may be implied (see Practice note, Contracts: force majeure: Only effective cause of default).

For so long as the Affected Party's liability in relation to any of its obligations is suspended under clause 21.2, the other party shall not be liable for any failure or delay in performing its corresponding obligations. To the extent that Services are not provided during a Force Majeure Event, the Supplier shall not charge the relevant Charges for those Services.

head.headtext: Effect of force majeure on other party's obligations (optional clause)

para.paratext: Consider whether this clause 21.3 is needed. It may not be necessary if the contract is structured so that completion and acceptance of services triggers the customer's payment obligation and the customer will therefore not be required to pay for as long as the supplier is unable to complete any services due to force majeure.
For more information on this provision, including the chances of it being implied if not included, see Practice note, Contracts: force majeure: Effect on unaffected party's obligations.
Clause 21.2 shall only apply if the Affected Party:
