as soon as reasonably practicable after the start of the Force Majeure Event [but no later than [NUMBER] days from its start], notifies the other party of the Force Majeure Event, the date on which it started, its likely or potential duration, and the effect of the Force Majeure Event on its ability to perform any of its obligations under this agreement;

took reasonable precautions to prevent or minimise the Force Majeure Event, including by implementing and complying with an effective business continuity plan, except where compliance with the business continuity plan is itself affected by the Force Majeure Event; and

uses all reasonable endeavours to mitigate the effect of the Force Majeure Event on the performance of its obligations (including by accepting non-contractual performance by the other party, provided this causes no material commercial detriment to the Affected Party and can achieve the same result as contractual performance would have done in all material respects).
The Affected Party shall keep the other party informed of its endeavours under clause 21.4(c) and their outcome [promptly on request OR in weekly written reports].
If the Supplier is relieved from providing any Services under this clause 21, it shall co-operate with any efforts that the Customer may make to obtain alternative supplies of those Services.

If the Affected Party has not resumed full performance of any obligations suspended under clause 21.2 within [NUMBER] days after the start of the Force Majeure Event, the other party may terminate this agreement by giving [not less than [NUMBER] days'] notice to the Affected Party.
This clause 22 addresses:
Each party's ability to transfer its rights and obligations under the agreement to a third party.
The supplier's ability to subcontract its obligations.

As a customer-friendly agreement, the clause restricts the supplier's ability to deal with its rights and obligations under the agreement without the customer's prior consent, whereas the customer is not subject to the same restrictions. The clause also contains drafting:
Making the supplier liable for its subcontractors.
Allowing the customer to withdraw its consent to subcontractors.
Requiring the supplier to "flow down" certain requirements of this agreement into its contracts with subcontractors.
For more information on assignment and other dealings clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Assignment and other dealings and its drafting notes.
For more information on supply chain flow-down terms and more detailed drafting, see Standard clause, Supply chain flow-down terms.

The Supplier shall not assign, novate, transfer, mortgage, charge, subcontract, delegate, declare a trust over or deal in any other manner with any or all of its rights and obligations under this agreement without the prior written consent of the Customer [(not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)].

The Customer may at any time assign, novate, transfer, mortgage, charge, subcontract, delegate, declare a trust over or deal in any other manner with any or all of its rights and obligations under this agreement[, provided that it gives prior notice to the Supplier].
The Customer consents to the Supplier subcontracting the elements of the Services identified in Schedule 3 to the subcontractors identified in Schedule 3.

The customer generally wants to have control over who is performing the services. It wants to avoid work being subcontracted to organisations that it does not want in its supply chain. That could be for a number of reasons, for example, because they are competitors or due to concerns about past performance.
Under this clause 22.3, the customer consents to the supplier using certain pre-approved subcontractors. Approval is required under clause 22.1.
Where the customer allows the supplier to subcontract, it will expect the supplier to remain responsible for the performance of the agreement.

Where the Supplier subcontracts any of its obligations under this agreement, the Supplier remains responsible for the performance of this agreement and liable for all acts and omissions of its subcontractors as if they were its own.
The Customer may withdraw its consent to using a subcontractor, by giving [reasonable prior] notice to the Supplier, where, in the Customer's reasonable opinion:

the acts or omissions of the relevant subcontractor have caused or materially contributed to the [Supplier being in breach of this agreement OR Customer having the right to terminate this agreement under clause 19.1(a)[, clause 19.1(b)][, clause 19.3(a)] [or clause 19.3(b)];
the acts or omissions of the subcontractor have brought the Customer into public disrepute, whether or not those acts or omissions relate to the Services; or
the continued use of that subcontractor will have a material adverse effect on the provision of the Services or the Customer's business or reputation.

head.headtext: Withdrawal of consent to subcontracting (optional clause)

para.paratext: From the customer's perspective, its consent to any subcontracting is contingent on the suitability and performance of the supplier's subcontractors. If a subcontractor is having a detrimental effect on the customer, then the customer will want the supplier to stop using that subcontractor.
Under clause 22.5(a) and clause 22.5(b), the customer can withdraw consent where the subcontractor has:
Caused the supplier to be in breach (first option) or material breach entitling the customer to terminate (second option).
Done something that brings the customer into public disrepute.
The optional drafting in clause 22.5(c) is broader, allowing the customer to withdraw consent before any adverse event has happened, and may therefore be harder to negotiate.

The supplier may object to this clause 22.5, pointing out that it remains responsible for the performance of the agreement and should therefore be free to decide how to manage its subcontractors. If the supplier accepts the premise of the clause, it may argue that it should only be obliged to stop using a subcontractor where an act or omission of the subcontractor has put the supplier in material breach of its contract with the customer. The supplier may argue that it should be indemnified for any costs or claims it incurs if it is obliged to stop using a subcontractor in any other situation. These might include costs of paying off the subcontractor and engaging an alternative subcontractor at a higher price.
Unless otherwise agreed by the Customer in writing, the Supplier shall ensure that each subcontract includes:

equivalent obligations and restrictions on the subcontractor to those imposed on the Supplier under this agreement by [clause 12 OR clause 12.1,] [clause 13 OR clause 13.7, clause 13.8 and clause 13.9,] [clause 14] and [OTHER CLAUSES TO FLOW DOWN];

a prohibition on any further subcontracting without the Supplier's prior written consent. The Supplier must obtain the Customer's prior written consent (not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed) before granting its consent to further subcontracting; and
any additional terms that the Customer reasonably requires as a condition of granting its consent to any subcontract.

The customer may want the supplier to flow down certain obligations in the agreement to its subcontractors. From the customer's perspective, this could be an important part of mitigating its risk of breaching laws that require it to police its supply chains (for example, by ensuring that bribery or modern slavery is not taking place within it).
By contrast, the supplier may see this as excessive and impractical.
Choose the first options in clause 22.6(a) to make the obligations that the supplier must flow-down broader. Use the second options to make them narrower and easier for the supplier to comply with.

A variation clause (sometimes called an amendments clause, a no variation clause, or a no oral modification clause) sets out a prescribed procedure for the parties to follow to vary the agreement. It is intended to exclude the possibility of informal, and perhaps inadvertent, oral variations being made to an agreement.
For more information on variation clauses, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Variation.

This clause 23 also includes optional wording to require a valid variation to expressly state that it is amending the agreement in question. This extra layer of formality may help to prevent variations being agreed inadvertently (for example, by email) before a proper amendment agreement has been drafted and reviewed by lawyers.
No variation of this agreement shall be effective unless it is in writing and signed by the parties (or their authorised representatives) [and expressly states that it is amending this agreement].
A waiver occurs when a party indicates that it will not exercise a right or remedy under a contract. This clause 24, sometimes known as a "no waiver" clause, seeks to ensure that:
A party's inadvertent failure to enforce its contractual rights or remedies does not result in losing those rights or remedies.
A waiver of a breach on one occasion does not affect the rights of the waiving party if there is a further breach.
For more information on waiver clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Waiver and its drafting notes.
A waiver of any right or remedy under this agreement or by law is only effective if given in writing and shall not be deemed to be a waiver of any subsequent right or remedy.

A failure or delay by a party to exercise any right or remedy provided under this agreement or by law shall not constitute a waiver of that or any other right or remedy, nor shall it prevent or restrict any further exercise of that or any other right or remedy. No single or partial exercise of any right or remedy provided under this agreement or by law shall prevent or restrict the further exercise of that or any other right or remedy.
For information on rights and remedies clauses, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Rights and remedies.
The rights and remedies provided under this agreement are in addition to, and not exclusive of, any rights or remedies provided by law.
The purpose of a severance clause is to clarify that if a term is invalid or unenforceable, the parties intend the rest of the agreement to continue without the invalid or unenforceable term.

This short-form severance clause does not include an obligation on the parties to negotiate in good faith to agree a replacement term. For drafting to that effect and for information on severance clauses generally, see Standard clause, Severance and its drafting notes.

If any provision or part-provision of this agreement is or becomes invalid, illegal or unenforceable, it shall be deemed deleted, but that shall not affect the validity and enforceability of the rest of this agreement.
An entire agreement clause confirms that the contract concerned contains the entire agreement between the parties and supersedes any previous agreements.

It can also be used to dissuade the courts from finding that statements or representations made outside of the contract form part of it. The customer is usually more likely to receive representations from the supplier during the lead-up to signing the contract than vice versa. The customer should therefore consider omitting clause 27.2 and clause 27.3 which are intended to:
Prevent liability in misrepresentation from arising in respect of pre-contractual statements that are not included in the agreement.
Exclude remedies for innocent and negligent misrepresentation that might otherwise be based on statements contained in the agreement
However, these elements are a common feature of entire agreement clauses and the supplier may insist on their inclusion and the customer's reliance on contract terms and contractual remedies.
For more information on entire agreement clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Entire agreement and its drafting notes.

This agreement constitutes the entire agreement between the parties and supersedes and extinguishes all previous and contemporaneous agreements, promises, assurances, and understandings between them, whether written or oral, relating to its subject matter.

[Subject to clause 16.2, each OR Each] party acknowledges that in entering into this agreement it does not rely on, and shall have no remedies in respect of, any statement, representation, assurance or warranty (whether made innocently or negligently) that is not set out in this agreement.
Each party agrees that it shall have no claim for innocent or negligent misrepresentation [or negligent misstatement] based on any statement in this agreement.
For information on conflict clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Conflict and its drafting notes.
If there is an inconsistency between any of the provisions in the main body of this agreement and the Schedules, the provisions in the main body of this agreement prevail.

An announcements clause prevents either party from making a public announcement about their agreement without the prior written consent of the other party. It is often the customer who wants to include this clause to stop the supplier publicly announcing the deal without the customer's permission.
For more information on announcement clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Announcements and its drafting notes.

No party shall make, or permit any person to make, any public announcement concerning the existence, subject matter or terms of this agreement, the wider transactions contemplated by it, or the relationship between the parties, without the prior written consent of the other party [(consent not to be unreasonably withheld or delayed)], except as required by law, any governmental or regulatory authority (including any relevant securities exchange), any court or other authority of competent jurisdiction.
The purpose of this clause 30 is to minimise the risk of an agreement creating an unwanted joint venture, partnership, employer-employee, or agency relationship between the parties.

If provisions are added to this agreement under which one party is permitted to act as the agent of the other, add a carve out to the end of clause 30.1 such as "except as expressly provided in clauses [NUMBERS]".
For more information on partnership and agency clauses, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, No partnership or agency.

Nothing in this agreement is intended to, or shall be deemed to, establish any partnership or joint venture between the parties, constitute either party as the agent of the other party, or authorise any party to make or enter into any commitments for or on behalf of the other party.
Each party confirms it is acting on its own behalf and not for the benefit of any other person.

Sometimes an entity which is not itself a party to a contract needs the right to enforce the terms of that contract against one of the contracting parties. For example, indemnities are sometimes drafted so that non-parties, such as affiliates, can benefit from the indemnity.

Use the optional opening words in clause 31.1 if a third party is given rights under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 (CROTPA) to enforce any terms in this agreement. There is also optional wording to name clauses where third party rights are created, such as:
Clause 3.3(d) under which customer affiliates can receive services.
The indemnity in clause 16.5.
If no third party is meant to benefit from any right or defence in the agreement, delete the optional opening words.
Clause 31.2 should only be used if third party rights have been granted. Delete it if all rights under CROTPA have been excluded.
For more information on third party rights clauses, see Standard clause, Third party rights and its drafting notes.

[Unless it expressly states otherwise [(including in clause 3.3(d) and clause 16.5)],] this agreement does not give rise to any rights under the Contracts (Rights of Third Parties) Act 1999 to enforce any term of this agreement.
The rights of the parties to rescind or vary this agreement are not subject to the consent of any other person.
This clause 32 governs how any notice under this agreement must be given and the time when the notice is deemed to have been formally received.
Clause 32.1(b) allows notices to be given by email. If removing this option, see also clause 1.9 and make sure the two provisions are consistent.
For more information on notices clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard clause, Notices and its drafting notes.
Any notice given to a party under or in connection with this agreement shall be in writing and shall be:
delivered by hand or by pre-paid first-class post or other next working day delivery service at its registered office (if a company) or its principal place of business (in any other case); or
sent by email to the following address (or an address substituted in writing by the party to be served):

This clause 32 does not apply to the service of any proceedings or any documents in any legal action or, where applicable, any arbitration or other method of dispute resolution.
For information on counterparts clauses and alternative drafting, see Standard document, Counterparts and its drafting notes.
This agreement may be executed in any number of counterparts, each of which constitutes a duplicate original, but all the counterparts together constitute the one agreement.

Transmission of [an executed counterpart of this agreement (but for the avoidance of doubt not just a signature page) OR the executed signature page of a counterpart of this agreement] by email (in PDF, JPEG or other agreed format) takes effect as the transmission of an executed "wet ink" counterpart of this agreement. [If this method of transmission is adopted, without prejudice to the validity of the agreement made, each party shall on request provide the other with the "wet ink" hard copy original[s] of their counterpart.]
For information on the drafting options in this clause 33.2, see Standard clause, Counterparts: Drafting note: Virtual signing process (optional clause).

The ongoing nature of a commercial agreement means that, if a dispute arises, formal dispute resolution proceedings should be a last resort. By providing for the parties to undertake some less formal stages of dispute resolution before beginning litigation or arbitration, a dispute resolution procedure can help to protect the relationship between the parties and save them significant amounts of time and money, when compared with litigation or arbitration.
This clause 34 provides a basic framework for the parties to try to resolve disputes through negotiation and mediation either before or in parallel to court or arbitration proceedings.
For information on dispute resolution clauses and alternative procedures, see the following Standard clauses and their drafting notes:
Multi-tiered dispute resolution procedure.
Expert determination.

Expert determination is typically used where a contract could raise a narrow technical question that an independent expert could resolve, such as a valuation or technical or professional opinion. As most services agreements do not need expert determination provisions, we have not included them in this draft.

If a dispute arises out of or in connection with this agreement or its performance, validity or enforceability (Dispute), then[, except as expressly provided in this agreement,] the parties shall follow the procedure set out in this clause:

either party shall notify the other of the Dispute, setting out its nature and full particulars (Dispute notice), together with relevant supporting documents. On service of the Dispute notice, the [EMPLOYEE TITLE] of the Customer and [EMPLOYEE TITLE] of the Supplier shall attempt in good faith to resolve the Dispute;

if the [EMPLOYEE TITLE] of the Customer and [EMPLOYEE TITLE] of the Supplier are for any reason unable to resolve the Dispute within [30] days of service of the Dispute notice, the Dispute shall be referred to the [SENIOR OFFICER TITLE] of the Customer and [SENIOR OFFICER TITLE] of the Supplier who shall attempt in good faith to resolve it; and

if the [SENIOR OFFICER TITLE] of the Customer and [SENIOR OFFICER TITLE] of the Supplier are for any reason unable to resolve the Dispute within [30] days of it being referred to them, the parties agree to enter into mediation in good faith to settle the Dispute and will do so in accordance with the [CEDR Model Mediation Procedure OR [PROCEDURE]]. Unless otherwise agreed between the parties within [NUMBER] days of service of the Dispute notice, the mediator shall be nominated by [CEDR OR [OTHER]]. To initiate the mediation, a party must serve notice in writing (ADR notice) to the other party to the Dispute, referring the Dispute to mediation. A copy of the ADR notice should be sent to [CEDR OR [OTHER]]; and
unless otherwise agreed between the parties, the mediation will start not later than [NUMBER] days after the date of the ADR notice.
[The start of mediation shall not prevent the parties starting or continuing court proceedings in relation to the Dispute.

Subject to clause 34.3, no party may commence any court proceedings in relation to the whole or part of the Dispute until it has attempted to settle the Dispute by mediation and either the mediation has terminated, or the other party has failed to participate in the mediation, provided that the right to issue proceedings is not prejudiced by a delay.]

head.headtext: Permitting or prohibiting parallel formal proceedings

para.paratext: The first option allows the dispute to be referred to court proceedings in parallel to the mediation.
The second option expressly prohibits court proceedings until after the mediation.
For more information on the drafting options in this clause, see Standard clause, Multi-tiered dispute resolution procedure: Drafting note: Permitting or prohibiting parallel formal proceedings.

If for any reason the Dispute is not resolved within [NUMBER] days of the start of the mediation, the Dispute shall be finally resolved by the courts of England and Wales in accordance with clause 36.
For information on governing law clauses, see the drafting notes to Standard clause, Governing law.

This agreement and any dispute or claim (including non-contractual disputes or claims) arising out of or in connection with it or its subject matter or formation shall be governed by and construed in accordance with the law of England and Wales.

For information on jurisdiction clauses and additional and alternative drafting (including for the appointment of a process agent in England and Wales where one of the parties is based overseas), see Standard clause, Jurisdiction and its drafting notes.

Each party irrevocably agrees that the courts of England and Wales shall have [exclusive OR non-exclusive] jurisdiction to settle any dispute or claim (including non-contractual disputes or claims) arising out of or in connection with this agreement or its subject matter or formation.
This agreement has been entered into on the date stated at the beginning of it.
Tips for drafting the description of the services and deliverables include:

Avoid relying on just the supplier's standard service description. Instead ensure that the services schedule reflects the customer's requirements and commits the supplier to any particular outcome which is important to the customer (for example, the achievement of a particular goal or a particular level of savings). Where there is both a customer's requirements document and a supplier's standard description of the services, avoid relying on both and specifying that one will take precedence. Any conflicts should be identified and the correct position stated in a single document.

Consider the services and deliverables to be provided in detail from end to end, step by step. Also consider how the supplier should respond to unusual events. For example, in the context of delivery services, the provision by the customer of an incorrect address.
Obtain input from the individuals involved in the operational aspects of the services so that the drafting reflects the realities of the provision of those services.

Consider the division of responsibilities between the parties and be clear on who is doing what. As part of the process, it may be helpful to insert each step of the services into a table and allocate it to one of the parties. This will help identify any areas where the supplier's performance is dependent on something the customer must do first. The wording should create clearly enforceable obligations so make clear who is doing each obligation, when they must do it and what needs to be done.

Avoid the use of subjective descriptions such as "good" or "satisfactorily" where possible as these may result in disputes as to whether those standards have been met. Instead, define the standards by measurable criteria. If you do use the term "satisfactory", make it clear that this is to be done to someone's satisfaction (ideally, the customer's although the supplier will want the customer to act reasonably).

Avoid leaving matters to be agreed by the parties as this will cause issues if the parties cannot subsequently agree. If something cannot be agreed upfront, try to include a detailed mechanism or formula for working out the relevant issue.

Consider including a reporting obligation. For example, the supplier must provide periodic reports on key information, as well as reporting on any specific events (for example, complaints from end-users or failure to comply with the description of the services).

As mentioned in Drafting note, Transfer of employees under TUPE, TUPE can apply where there is a "service provision change". In a supply of services context, TUPE should be considered at the start (TUPE on entry) and the end (TUPE on exit) of any part of the services:

TUPE on entry. At the start of the services, if TUPE applies, then employees of the customer or a former supplier who have been allocated to providing substantially equivalent services transfer from the customer or former supplier to the supplier. As the supplier will be taking on these individuals, it may want contractual protection (in the form of warranties and indemnities) to cover any losses arising from those transfers. In a pro-customer agreement, the customer may choose to include no TUPE on entry provisions and leave it to the supplier to request them. However, the customer should bear in mind that the supplier is likely to ask for TUPE on entry protections where the supplier is being asked to provide TUPE on exit protections. Providing some TUPE on entry provisions may help the customer to obtain the TUPE on exit provisions that it wants and minimise negotiations.

TUPE on exit. At the end of the services, if TUPE applies, then the supplier's employees who were allocated to providing those services may transfer either back to the customer or to a replacement supplier. The customer will want to seek appropriate TUPE warranties and indemnities for its own benefit and the benefit of any replacement supplier. A replacement supplier may look to the customer to secure protection for it against any liabilities it inherits under TUPE.
For more information on TUPE provisions on entry and exit, see Practice note, Outsourcing agreements: drafting and negotiating employment indemnities and warranties.
This schedule includes two options:

Option 1. This option assumes that TUPE is unlikely to apply on entry or exit, for example, because there is no organised grouping of employees dedicated to providing the services. This option includes customer-friendly drafting so that the supplier has to redeploy staff to avoid TUPE applying on exit. If any supplier personnel claim to have transferred to the customer or a replacement supplier on exit, the customer (or replacement supplier) can terminate their employment and the supplier indemnifies them against any resulting liabilities. The customer effectively transfers the risk of TUPE applying onto the supplier.

Option 2. This option assumes that TUPE is likely to apply on entry and exit. The TUPE on entry provisions are basic as they generally protect the supplier. The TUPE on exit provisions are more detailed as the customer or a replacement supplier is likely to inherit staff on exit and want protection from the supplier.

As a standard services agreement (rather than an outsourcing), the provisions in option 2 are relatively short form. For more information about them, and a more comprehensive set of TUPE provisions on entry and exit, see Standard clause, Outsourcing agreement: employment provisions: Schedule 2. This standard clause includes:
An extensive set of customer undertakings, warranties and indemnities on entry.
Clauses giving the customer or replacement supplier the option to offer employment to employees who are not in-scope to transfer on exit under TUPE.

paratext.ital: Option 1: Terms for when TUPE is not expected to apply

para.paratext: Each party agrees that neither the start nor the termination of the Services (or any part of them) is expected to constitute a relevant transfer for the purposes of the Employment Regulations.

The Supplier shall, if requested to do so by the Customer at any time during the period of [three] months before the termination or expiry of any of the Services (Rundown Period), [use all reasonable endeavours to] organise the Supplier Personnel in such a way that none of them transfer to the Customer or a Replacement Supplier on termination or expiry of the Services.

If, despite paragraph 2, the employment or engagement of any Supplier Person is found or alleged to have transferred to the Customer or a Replacement Supplier by virtue of this agreement or the Employment Regulations on the termination or expiry of this agreement, then:
the Customer shall notify the Supplier within [NUMBER] days of becoming aware of that fact;
the Supplier may, within [NUMBER] days after the date of the notice in paragraph 3.1, make an offer of employment or engagement to the relevant person (or procure that a subcontractor does);

the Customer shall release, or procure that the Replacement Supplier releases, the relevant person from their employment or engagement if the offer is accepted or, if no offer is made or accepted, terminate (or procure the termination of) their employment or engagement within [NUMBER] days of the expiry of the [NUMBER] day period referred to in paragraph 3.2; and

the Supplier shall indemnify the Customer and Replacement Supplier against all Losses incurred by them as a result of the employment or engagement of the relevant person until that relationship is terminated and all Losses arising out of the termination itself[, provided that the Customer takes, or procures that the Replacement Supplier takes, reasonable steps to minimise those Losses].

The supplier may want the indemnity to not apply where losses are caused by the customer's or replacement supplier's acts or omissions, for example, discrimination or failure to follow a fair dismissal procedure. In this case, use the wording in brackets in paragraph 3.4.

paratext.ital: Option 2: short-form Customer-friendly terms for when TUPE may apply at the start and the end of the services.

para.paratext: In this Schedule 6, the following definitions apply (in addition to those in clause 1.1):

Employees: those employees [and workers] whose contracts transfer to the Supplier from the Customer or a Former Supplier, pursuant to the Employment Regulations, as at the Effective Date, and whose names appear in ANNEX A.

Exit Transferring Employees: those employees [and workers] whose contracts transfer to the Customer or a Replacement Supplier pursuant to the Employment Regulations on termination of the Services (in whole or in part).
Former Supplier: a supplier supplying services to the Customer before the Effective Date that are the same as or substantially similar to the Services (or any part of the Services).
Service Transfer: has the meaning given in paragraph 6.1.
Service Transfer Date: the date on which the Services (or the relevant part of the Services) transfer from the Supplier to the Customer or a Replacement Supplier.

Staffing Information: any information that the Customer may reasonably request in relation to persons detailed on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List or Supplier's Final Staff List, as the case may be, including:

Supplier's Final Staff List: the list of all Supplier Personnel wholly or mainly engaged in or assigned to the provision of the Services (or the relevant part of the Services subject to a Service Transfer) at the Service Transfer Date.

Supplier's Provisional Staff List: a list prepared and updated by the Supplier of all the Supplier Personnel wholly or mainly engaged in or assigned to the provision of the Services (or the relevant part of the Services subject to a Service Transfer) at the date of preparation of the list.

head.headtext: Transfer of Employees to the Supplier at the Effective Date

para.paratext: The Customer and the Supplier believe that, pursuant to the Employment Regulations, at the Effective Date, the Supplier will become the employer of the Employees.

If the services transfer to the supplier on a date other than the effective date (for example, where services actually start and transfer on a date after this contract is signed), include a definition for that date (for example, "Services Commencement Date") and replace references to the Effective Date with references to this date.

The Customer shall be responsible for all salaries and other compensation and benefits, including holiday pay, taxation and National Insurance contributions and contributions to retirement benefit schemes, relating to the Employees up to the Effective Date and the Supplier shall be responsible for them from and including the Effective Date.

The Customer shall indemnify the Supplier against all Losses incurred by the Supplier as a result of anything done or omitted to be done by the Customer [or the Former Supplier] in respect of any of the Employees before the Effective Date. [The Customer shall not be liable under this indemnity to the extent that any Losses result from an act or omission of the Supplier, including any failure to comply with its obligations under the Employment Regulations.]

If staff transfer from a former supplier to the new supplier, the customer should make sure it has indemnity protection from the former supplier in relation to its acts or omissions before indemnifying the supplier against the former supplier's acts or omissions. If the customer does not have this indemnity protection, the best position for the customer is to omit references to the former supplier in this indemnity, although the supplier may see that as inadequate.
The Supplier shall indemnify the Customer [and Former Supplier] against all Losses incurred by the Customer [or Former Supplier] as a result of:
any failure by the Supplier to comply with its obligations under the Employment Regulations in relation to the transfer of the Employees; or
anything done or omitted to be done by the Supplier in respect of any of the Employees whether before, on or after the Effective Date.

The parties acknowledge and agree that the identity of the provider of the Services (or any part of the Services) may change (whether as a result of the expiry or termination of this agreement, in whole or in part, or otherwise) resulting in a transfer of the Services in whole or in part (Service Transfer). If a Service Transfer is a relevant transfer for the purposes of the Employment Regulations, each party shall comply [(and the Customer shall use reasonable endeavours to procure that any Replacement Supplier complies)] with its respective obligations under the Employment Regulations in respect of the Exit Transferring Employees.

The Supplier shall provide the Supplier's Provisional Staff List and the Staffing Information (in a suitably anonymised format where necessary to comply with Applicable Data Protection Laws) to the Customer or, at the direction of the Customer, to a Replacement Supplier within [14] days of:
the date which is [six] months before the expiry of the Term;
giving or receiving notice of termination of this agreement (in whole or in part); or
receipt of a written request from the Customer to do so.

The Supplier shall provide an updated Supplier's Provisional Staff List and Staffing Information [if any of the information [materially] changes or] when reasonably requested by the Customer or any Replacement Supplier.

At least 28 days before the Service Transfer Date (or, if special circumstances make this not reasonably practicable, as soon as reasonably practicable thereafter), the Supplier shall provide the Supplier's Final Staff List and Staffing Information to the Customer or, at the direction of the Customer, to a Replacement Supplier. The Supplier's Final Staff List shall identify which of the Supplier Personnel are Exit Transferring Employees.

The Supplier warrants and represents that all information provided under paragraph 6.2, paragraph 6.3 and paragraph 6.4 shall be complete and accurate in all material respects at the time it is provided.

Subject to clause 14, the Customer may use and disclose the Supplier's Provisional Staff List, the Supplier's Final Staff List and the Staffing Information for informing any tenderer or other prospective supplier of Replacement Services.

From the date which is [six] months before the expiry of the Term or immediately following giving or receiving notice to terminate this agreement (whichever is earlier), the Supplier shall not [(and shall procure that its subcontractors shall not)], without the prior written consent of the Customer:
assign any person to the provision of the Services (or the relevant part which is the subject of a Service Transfer) who is not listed in the Supplier's Provisional Staff List;
increase the number of persons on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List save for fulfilling assignments and projects previously scheduled and agreed with the Customer;

make, propose or permit any [material] changes to the terms and conditions of any of the people listed on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List [other than salary increases in the ordinary course of business];

increase the proportion of working time spent on the Services (or the relevant part) by any Supplier Personnel save for fulfilling assignments and projects previously scheduled and agreed with the Customer;

introduce any new contractual or customary practice concerning the making of any lump sum payment on the termination of employment of any employees listed on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List; and

replace any of the Supplier Personnel listed on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List or deploy any other person to perform the Services (or the relevant part) or terminate or give notice to terminate the employment or contracts of any persons on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List[, except as a result of a disciplinary process properly carried out].

The Supplier shall promptly notify the Customer or, at the direction of the Customer, the Replacement Supplier, of any notice to terminate employment or engagement given by the Supplier or any subcontractor to, or received by the Supplier or any subcontractor from, any persons listed on the Supplier's Provisional Staff List regardless of when that notice takes effect.

Each party shall co-operate [(and the Customer shall use reasonable endeavours to procure that the Replacement Supplier co-operates)] to fulfil any requirement to inform and consult appropriate representatives in relation to any relevant transfer under the Employment Regulations that results from a Service Transfer.

[At least [NUMBER] days before OR within [NUMBER] days after] the Service Transfer Date, the Supplier shall provide to the Customer, or any Replacement Supplier nominated by the Customer, in respect of each person on the Supplier's Final Staff List who is an Exit Transferring Employee:
pay slip data for the most recent month;
cumulative pay for tax and pension purposes;
cumulative tax paid;
tax code;
details of voluntary deductions from pay;
a copy of the personnel file or other records regarding the service of the Exit Transferring Employee; and
bank or building society account details for payroll purposes.

The Supplier shall, and shall procure that each subcontractor shall, perform and discharge all its obligations in respect of all the Exit Transferring Employees arising in the period up to and including the Service Transfer Date.
The Supplier shall indemnify the Customer and Replacement Supplier against all Losses incurred by the Customer or Replacement Supplier as a result of:
any failure by the Supplier or any subcontractor to comply with paragraph 6.11;
any failure by the Supplier or any subcontractor to comply with its obligations under the Employment Regulations in respect of any Exit Transferring Employee;
anything done or omitted to be done by the Supplier or any subcontractor in respect of any Exit Transferring Employee on or before the Service Transfer Date; or

any claim or threatened claim by any person employed or engaged (or formerly employed or engaged) by the Supplier or any subcontractor who alleges that they have transferred to the Customer or the Replacement Supplier by virtue of this agreement or the Employment Regulations but whose name is not included in the Supplier's Final Staff List as an Exit Transferring Employee. This indemnity includes all Losses arising out of the employment or engagement of the relevant person by the Customer or Replacement Supplier until that relationship is terminated and all Losses arising out of the termination itself[, provided that the Customer takes, or procures that the Replacement Supplier takes, reasonable steps to minimise those Losses].

The Customer shall indemnify the Supplier against all Losses incurred by the Supplier as a result of anything done or omitted to be done by the Customer [or the Replacement Supplier] in respect of any Exit Transferring Employee(s) after the Service Transfer Date.
The customer may not want to offer this indemnity in a first draft but the supplier may ask for it where the customer is asking the supplier for the indemnities in paragraph 6.12.
If the customer is giving this indemnity in relation to the acts or omissions of the replacement supplier, it should ensure it has appropriate indemnity protection from the replacement supplier.

The Supplier shall provide, and procure that each subcontractor provides, all reasonable co-operation to the Customer and any Replacement Supplier to ensure the smooth transfer of the Exit Transferring Employees on the Service Transfer Date.
